story: The European Commission President was prompted to speak first, to which he asked whether French or English would be the most suitable language to address the waiting journalists and onlookers.When told English would be best for his speech, Mr Juncker quipped: &ldquoShame on you.The European Union&rsquos most senior official proceeded to laugh along with the crowd before making his speech in English.Mr Juncker has previously spoke about the English language &ldquolosing importance after Britain decided to quit the EU after the historic June 2016 referendum.                Brexit news: Juncker tells EU not to harm UK after KILLING Chequers                 Nigel Farage claims EU leaders want to 'humiliate' Britain in tiradeIn May last year, the eurocrat told a conference in Italy that &ldquoEnglish is losing importance in Europe.He told the crowd he would deliver his speech in French amid tensions with the UK over looming Brexit negotiations.&ldquoSlowly but surely English is losing importance in Europe and also because France has an election, Mr Juncker said, explaining his choice of language.In his September 23 speech at the UN&rsquos headquarters in New York, Mr Juncker spoke of the importance of a &ldquomultilateral approach to politics.Jean-Claude Juncker jokes after being told to speak English at United Nations speech (Image: EbS)He explained &ldquomultilateralism to be a &ldquobridge to a better humanity, a better world.Mr Jucnker said: &ldquoAntonio Guterres now is the secretary general of the United Nations. We came here to express admiration for him because he is doing an excellent job.&ldquoWe are also here to say that the multilateral approach is not dead, it has to be maintained &ndash it is the only chance we have to shape the future of the globe in a way which is acceptable for all the stakeholders.&ldquoWe do not like the unilateral approach. We do think that multilateralism has to have a chance.&ldquoIt is difficult but the only avenue for the future. We are supporting actively and fully the UN system &ndash the United Nations &ndash because with your work you pave the way to a better future.&ldquoThe United Nations are the cornerstone of multilateralism, the bridge to a better humanity, a better world.&ldquoThe European Union will remain the close partner of the United Nations and of Ant&oacutenio Guterres.Mr Guterres praised Mr Juncker and the EU for being an &ldquoexemplary partner of the UN, adding: &ldquoWe share the same common ground: in favour of multilateralism and in favour of a rules-based international order.

title: Labour conference Labour Party 2018 news John McDonnell manifesto BBC CBI business
story: Shadow chancellor John McDonnell in his keynote conference speech today is set to say that under a Labour Government every firm with more than 250 staff will be expected to set up an &ldquoinclusive ownership fund from its profits if Labour seizes power at the next general election.Under the Labour frontbenchers&rsquo latest policy, firms will be mandated to pay all staff a idend of up to &pound500 a year from the fund under plans to drastically increase employee ownership, he will say.But the CBI boss warned the policy is likely to &ldquoharm Labour voters' pay and negatively impact business&rsquo investment and productivity.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, Ms Fairbairn said: &ldquoThe right question is being asked here, it&rsquos just that the answer is one that would have such a negative effect on investment and productivity and, therefore, pay.                'FUDGE' Labour plans to REFUSE to rule out supporting new referendum                Embarrassing! Jeremy Corbyn C by Julia Hartley-Brewer&ldquoActually, the very people the&nbspLabour Party&nbspare trying to help would be harmed. We think there are other and better ways of getting to the same outcome.She added: &ldquoYou&rsquove got to remember that we are under the spotlight as a country at the moment.&ldquoCompetitiveness is everything - our every move is being watched.&ldquoShareholders are watching like hawks and we are in no doubt that share prices would fall. That&nbspeffects&nbspthe ability of companies to invest.&ldquoThat, in turn, effects productivity and pay and it would have an immediate effect.Labour conference: CBI boss says Labour policy will have negative impact on businesses (Image: Bloomberg&bull)The Tories have also said the move is simply another tax on business, with MP Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, saying: &ldquoThis proposal is yet another tax rise from a party that already wants to hike taxes to their highest level in peacetime history.&ldquoIt would make it harder for local businesses to take on staff and pay them a good wage. Business leaders also condemned the plans.Any cash left in the fund at the end of the financial year after the payments to staff will have to be handed over to the Government for increased state spending.The levy will come on top of higher corporation tax and increased income tax for top earners planned by Labour.Mr McDonnell will claim that 11 million employees &ndash around four out of every 10 people with jobs in the private sector &ndash could get payments from the new company idend funds.He is expected to say: &ldquoThe idend payments workers will receive will be up to &pound500 a year. That&rsquos 11 million workers each with a greater say, and a greater stake, in the rewards of their labour.&ldquoWe believe it&rsquos right that we all share in the benefits that investment produces.&ldquoThat&rsquos why a proportion of revenues generated by the &lsquoinclusive ownership funds&rsquo will be transferred back to our public services as a social idend.

title: brexit news remainers eu exit chequers conservative party
story: The ComRes survey, commissioned by pro-Brexit campaigning group Brexit Express, focused on 12 constituencies which are home to MPs who voted Remain in the 2016 referendum, including Dominic Grieve's Beaconsfield and Nicky Morgan's Loughborough.It suggests more than half of adults living in the constituencies polled &ndash 53 percent &ndash would consider voting for a political party with one single aim to put pressure on the main political parties to conclude Brexit &ldquoas quickly and fully as possible.Seventy percent of voters would switch vote in order to achieve the best Brexit outcome, while 83 percent of voters believe the Government stronger if they presented a united frontIn addition, 63 percent say MPs should back manifesto commitment to take UK out of EU, while 60 percent of Tory voters felt their MP was wrong to vote to stay in the Customs Union.                Brexit: Lord Adonis 'lives in a world of his own' says Brexiteer                Top Tory donor plots NEW PARTY to fight for 'true' BrexitAdditionally, 70 percent, including 70 percent of those who voted Conservative in the 2017 general election, said they were prepared to vote for a party they would not otherwise vote for in order to achieve Brexit.Meanwhile 31 percent of all voters, and 47 percent of Conservative voters, believed the Government should be prepared to walk away without a deal if the EU tries to force further concessions to Theresa May&rsquos &lsquoChequers&rsquo proposal.More than four in five voters living in the constituencies polled (83 percent) think the British Government will have more negotiating power over Brexit if the Conservative Party present a united frontThis figure significantly increases amongst Conservative voters themselves (93 percent vs 71 percent of Labour voters).Nicky Morgan is one of the MPs whose constituency was polled (Image: )Voters in Remainer Dominic Grieve's constituency were also surveyed (Image: )Brexit Express founder and City financier Jeremy Hosking said: &ldquoThese poll findings illustrate very clearly the failure of our political classes to grasp the strength of feeling among their own electorate, and in particular that voters expect their MPs to honour the commitments they made when they were elected.&nbsp&ldquoThe Baker&rsquos Dozen are the perfect example of a wilful blindness caused by terminal arrogance.&ldquoWhat this tells me is there is a chasm of a gap in the British political marketplace and Brexit Express will continue to help to fill it.Mr Hosking&rsquos comments come after a weekend in which he confirmed he was considering launching a party with the single aim of getting the UK out of the EU.                Jeremy Hosking hopes to fund campaign to oust pro-Remain MPs                Brexit news: Ex-minister WARNS Tory Brexiteers of no deal scenario ...Jeremy Hosking launched Brexit Express two years ago (Image: )Writing in The , he said: &ldquoThe Brexit Express has had enough. We must find some way of hopping out of the bubbling water.&ldquoThis is why we have been sponsoring opinion polls in both Tory and Labour constituencies.&ldquoThis polling shows there is clear support for a Brexit party that will deliver what the electorate thought it would be getting.&ldquoThe obvious question for Eurosceptics to ask is whether the current fiasco is accidental or premeditated.&ldquoThe more plausible theory by a distance is a deliberate attempt by the British establishment to render a real exit from the EU impossible.Mr Hosking donated &pound1.5 million to Vote Leave, the official pro-Brexit campaign during the 2016 referendum.He has given &pound375,000 to the Conservative Party since 2015.ComRes surveyed 4,110 British adults (343 Aberconwy, 339 Eddisbury, 343 Totnes, 300 Beaconsfield, 300 Maidenhead, 317 Bromley &amp Chislehurst, 318 South Cambridgeshire, 314 Broxtowe, 318 Huntingdon, 317 Rushcliffe, 301 Loughborough, 300 Bracknell, 300 Wimbledon) via telephone between 20th August 20 and 16th September 16 2018.&nbspData were weighted by gender, age and EU Referendum vote at a constituency level.

title: speed limit 20mph installed driver crackdown scotland uk
story: Green MSP Mark Ruskell has attracted cross-party support for his member's Bill, which could come law by the end of next year.City of Edinburgh Council has already rolled out 20mph zones across the capital, including some of its busiest roads.But the Restricted Roads (20 mph Speed Limit) (Scotland) Bill would introduce the slowdown nationwide.Any council which wanted to retain the 30mph limit would have to go through an application process.                Councils 'spending &pound11 MILLION' on 20mph zones across UK - and deat...                Speeding ticket: How to challenge a fine and actually win - even if...The Greens say it will make streets safer for pedestrians, reduce accidents and cut pollution.But motoring groups have warned a blanket limit will not cut casualties while hauliers fear it will damage business, hitting the economy.Mr Ruskell's bid has backing from road safety charity Brake, the British Heart Foundation and the British Lung Foundation.Today he received support from world record-breaking adventure cyclist Mark Beaumont.Beaumont, who cycled 18,000 miles around the world in less than 79 days, who said cutting the limit makes bags of sense.He added: Scotland has a real chance to take a lead on this so let's go for it.Motorists will face a speed crackdown with a 20mph speed limit to be imposed in built up areas  (Image: )The legislation was formally introduced after securing the support of 20 MSPs from the SNP, Greens and Labour, including the parliamentary aides of Nicola Sturgeon, John Swinney and Derek Mackay. However, Scots Tories warned it is unnecessary.If the Bill passes, local authorities are likely to be given 18 months to erect signs, before bringing the legislation into force.It is estimated it will cost councils &pound21 million to &pound22 million in the first two years. The bill for new signs is around &pound10 million per year.A Scottish Government marketing campaign to raise awareness of the new limit is projected to cost &pound450,000 per year for two years.Meanwhile, prosecution and courts costs will rise by &pound516,150 and &pound965,774 per year based on a estimated 20 per cent increase in speeding offences.                Driver WARNING: You could soon be fined &pound100 for travelling just 1m...                Motorway speed limits could rise to 80mph in the UK - but there is ...But it is claimed it will save the country &pound183 million a year by avoiding 54 fatal, 136 serious and 1,912 slight injuries.Neil Grieg, policy director at the road safety charity IAM Roadsmart, rejected the arguments for a blanket approachHe said: All roads differ in their form and function at a very detailed level and the limit should reflect that.If you want to change driver behaviour you need to spend more and change the character of the road.A car speeding in a residential area (Image: )That means more high quality surfacing and shared space. Drivers will get the message and share the road even more safely than they do already.But Mr Ruskell said: As a local councillor and as an MSP I have seen first-hand the frustration of communities that want lower speed limits but find the current process overly-complicated.By making 20 the norm in built-up areas we can end this frustration and provide the clarity that residents and motorists deserve.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: &ldquoWe are clear that 20 mile per hour speed limits are a good idea when implemented in the right environment.Given the varied nature of Scotland's urban road network and the number of factors which need considered when setting appropriate limits, we believe decisions on 20 mph speed limits are best taken at the local authority level.The Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity met with Mark Ruskell MSP regarding his plans to bring forward a Member&rsquos Bill on 20 mph speed limits and we look forward to seeing the detail of any legislative proposals which are submitted to Parliament.

title: brexit latest pet travel eu cat dog travel preparations europe no deal Brexit update
story: Owners of pets will have to discuss their plans with their vets when travelling to Europe (Image: )Owners of cats, dogs and ferrets could have to discuss their plans with their vet at least four months in advance, depending on what category of third country the UK becomes if it quits the EU without a deal.In its latest raft of no-deal technical notices, the Government said it was seeking discussions with the European Commission to allow the UK to become a listed third country.Under the best case, this would mean little change in pet travel arrangements.But if the UK crashes out without agreement and becomes an unlisted country on March 29, there could be a four-month turnaround for securing a health certificate proving pets are effectively vaccinated for rabies.This means anyone planning to travel on March 30 would need to discuss requirements with their vet before the end of November, the technical notice says.                Brexit: No-deal could ban coaches and flights in EU                Brexit news: 186 days to go - will Theresa May deliver a deal?Pets will need an up-to-date rabies vaccination and then wait 30 days for a blood test (Image: )Pets that have had a blood titre test - which demonstrates they have enough of the rabies antibody - and whose vaccinations are up to date would not have to repeat the test before travel.Those which have not had the blood test, but whose rabies vaccinations are up-to-date, would have to have the test done before travel, and there would then be a three-month waiting period to make sure no symptoms develop.Pets without an up-to-date rabies vaccination will need to be vaccinated and then wait 30 days before having the blood test, with another three-month wait before they can travel to the EU.Owners would have to get a health certificate issued by their vet for every trip to the EU, within 10 days before travel.Then they would go though a specified point of entry in the country they are travelling to have their pet's documents and identity checked.

title: Brexit news Graham Stringer EU UK withdrawal Macron Salzburg summit Chequers latest
story: The Labour Brexiteer did not mince his words as he delivered a harsh takedown of the European Union after the bloc shot down Britain's proposals for an orderly Brexit.Theresa May attended a crucial meeting with the leaders of the EU27 in Salzburg last week but her Chequers plan was brutally rejected as a threat to the single marker.Commenting on the EU's behaviour during the 2018 Labour Party Conference in Liverpool, Mr Stringer told Express: I think everything since the referendum in 2016 has validated what those others who believe the United Kingdom should leave the EU have been saying.They are arrogant, undemocratic, have no respect for the people of Europe. You can go back to Ireland, France, Denmark, all had referenda that the EU Commission didn&rsquot like and they&rsquove all been told to vote again.                'Hard to see majority for that!' Benn DISMANTLES calls for new vote                What is a Canada style Brexit deal? What did the IEA proposal say?Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat admitted there is an almost unanimous support among the remaining EU member states for a second Brexit vote to revert the result of the 2016 referendum.But zeroing on the bloc's leaders demanding a rerun of the vote &ndash including President Emmanuel Macron, who branded Brexiteer politicians liars &ndash Mr Stringer insisted their behaviour demonstrated the fact Brussels is not a democratic organisation.He said: We now have the leader of Malta telling us we should hold a second referendum. We have the President of France telling us that people who argued to leave the European Union &ndash itself a corrupt organisation &ndash are liars without specifying what he meant.I just think the EU has behaved in an arrogant way in the way they always have done and it highlights the fact that it&rsquos not a democratic organisation.Brexit news: Stringer branded the European Union as arrogant and undemocratic  (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bull)Labour councillor Brendan Chilton echoed Mr Stringer's feelings about the European Union, urging the EU to stop interfering on domestic affairs in Britain.Mr Chilton told Express: We had this in the referendum itself when we had EU leaders interfering in what was a domestic referendum. We had the President of the United States brought over in some attempt to frighten us into staying in and it failed.Frankly, I don&rsquot think the British people will like being told what to do by unelected people. Certainly, we didn&rsquot elect the Maltese president.I think he should focus on affairs in his own country and stop trying to interfere in the domestic affairs of this country.Additional reporting by Darren Hunt and Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.&nbsp

title: brexit news eu uk no deal plans ulk government plans latest
story: His comments came as the Government published 24 more papers to show preparations and plans in the event of a &ldquono deal with the EU.The prospect of a no deal appears to be more likely after EU leaders last week took a hard line and refused to negotiate over Theresa May&rsquos Chequers plans.Mr Raab, speaking to BBC News, said: The point of these technical notices and we've published 24 today, a total of 77 from aviation to motor insurance to taking your pet abroad, the kind of quality of life issues people care about, yes there is some risks of short term disruption, but we're giving the guidance, we're giving the information so that everyone knows what they need to do well in advance.Business groups like the CBI and others have been involved in Project Fear warnings over what would happen with a no deal.                What is a Canada style Brexit deal? What did the IEA proposal say?                No deal could spark air travel CHAOS if UK permissions aren&rsquot metHowever, Economists for Free Trade, led by Margaret Thatcher&rsquos former advisor Professor Patrick Minford, estimate that it could boost Britain by more than &pound1 trillion while hitting the EU by &pound500 billion.However, businesses warned that there would be short term disruption as a result of no deal.Federation of Small Businesses chairman Mike Cherry said: Last week's summit in Salzburg laid bare the volatility of the current Brexit negotiations and has heightened concerns among our small businesses whose confidence has already dipped into negative territory.These worries would have only intensified after studying the latest Government no-deal technical notes. So far, the Government has released three tranches of information that have really made clear that a chaotic no-deal Brexit will be damaging and dangerous for our small firms.Many smaller firms rely on hauliers for delivering goods across the EU and for bringing goods in. A no-deal Brexit could pose a real threat to these businesses as EU community licences issued by the UK might not be automatically recognised by the EU.Brexit no-deal: The UK has released its latest plans (Image: )Paul Everitt, chief executive of aviation group ADS, said: It is clearer than ever that a no-deal Brexit risks disruption to air passengers and businesses in aviation, aerospace and many other sectors across our economy.Flights between the EU and UKIf the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 with no agreement in place, UK and EU licensed airlines would lose the automatic right to operate air services between the UK and the EU without seeking advance permission.This would mean that airlines operating between the UK and the EU would need to seek inidual permissions to operate. EU-licensed airlines would lose the ability to operate wholly within the UK (for example from Heathrow to Edinburgh) and UK-licensed airlines would lose the ability to operate intra-EU air services (for example from Milan to Paris).In this scenario the UK would envisage granting permission to EU airlines to continue to operate. We would expect EU countries to reciprocate in turn.                Brexit news: 186 days to go - will Theresa May deliver a deal?                'Hard to see majority for that!' Benn DISMANTLES calls for new voteTaking your pet abroadIf the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 with no deal, it would become a third country for the purposes of the EU Pet Travel Scheme.Pets would continue to be able to travel from the UK to the EU, but the requirements for documents and health checks would differ depending on what category of third country the UK becomes on the day we leave the EU.The Government is seeking technical discussions with the European Commission to allow the UK to become a listed third country on the day the UK leaves the EU. We will continue to press the Commission to discuss this option with us.Plant imports and exportsIn a &lsquono deal&rsquo scenario, the UK would become a third country, and would need to meet EU third country import requirements to export controlled plants and plant products to the EU, including controls on all plants for planting and all wood packaging material.To deliver a smooth transition when we leave the EU, in a &lsquono deal&rsquo scenario the Government has decided that the majority of plants and plant products are low-risk and should continue to enter the UK from the EU freely, as they do now.If the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 with no deal it can impact the EU Pet Travel Scheme (Image: )CopyrightThe UK&rsquos continued membership of the main international treaties on copyright will ensure that the scope of protection for copyright works (ie music, literature) in the UK and for UK works abroad will remain largely unchanged.The EU cross-border copyright mechanisms extend only to member states of the EU or EEA. On exit, the UK will be treated by the EU and EEA as a third country and the reciprocal element of these mechanisms will cease to apply to the UK.Protecting geographical food and drink namesWhen Britain leaves the EU it will set up our own Geographical Identification (GI) schemes which will be World Trade Organisation compliant, broadly mirror the current EU regime and be no more burdensome to producers.It means EU producers such as champagne producers will have to make new GI applications to the UK.There will also be a new UK logo trade mark with Brexit.After we leave the EU, the Government anticipates that all current UK GIs will continue to be protected by the EU&rsquos GI schemes and vice versa.Vehicle insuranceIf the UK leaves the EU in March 2019 with no deal in place regarding the implementation period and future arrangements, access to the Green Card-free circulation area would cease. This would mean that UK motorists would need to carry a Green Card as proof of third party motor insurance cover when driving in the EU, EEA, Andorra, Serbia and Switzerland.

title: Brexit news Kate Hoey EU UK withdrawal latest Theresa May Salzburg Chequers latest
story: The Labour Brexiteer insisted the disrespect shown toward the Prime Minister during the Brexit summit in Austria had kickstarted a shift in support towards a harder strategy.&nbspTheresa May met with top European Union bureaucrats and the leaders of the EU27 to promote her Chequers proposal for a future trade deal after Brexit but was summarily dismissed.Asked whether a true Brexit could still happen after the EU's rejection, Ms Hoey exclusively told Express: I think it&rsquos quite clear now that even in the last few days there&rsquos been a shift within the Conservative Party because of the way the EU has behaved.&nbspThe EU just weren&rsquot rude and disrespectful to the Prime Minister, they were rude and disrespectful to our country.                'Hard to see majority for that!' Benn DISMANTLES calls for new vote                Labour councillor HITS BACK at EU leaders urging UK to cancel BrexitMs Hoey added: I&rsquove met a lot of people who&rsquove felt very angry and I think they will just change.In a fiery speech aimed squarely at the EU, Mrs May declared she would never agree to proposals which would see Northern Ireland cut off from the rest of the UK by remaining in the bloc&rsquos customs union and much of the single market.And she hit out at Europe's &ldquounacceptable attitude to the talks, demanding the bloc return the respect the UK has extended and attempt to reach a compromise rather than simply rejecting the UK&rsquos offer.The Prime Minister said the EU has refused to budge on its position over a soliton to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic and is offering the UK just two options.Brexit news: Hoey said the EU's  (Image: SKY NEWS&bullEXPRESS.CO.UK)Mrs May said: &ldquoThe first option would involve the UK staying in the EEA and a customs union with the EU.&ldquoIn plain English, this would mean we would still have to abide by all the EU rules.&ldquoUncontrolled immigration from the EU would continue and we couldn&rsquot do trade deals we want with other countries. that would make a mockery of the referendum we had two years ago.In his response to Mrs May, EU Council President Donald Tusk described Mrs May's controversial Chequers plan for Brexit as a step in the right direction.But he claimed the UK's stance at the European Council summit in Austria yesterday was surprisingly tough and uncompromising.Striking a conciliatory tone, Mr Tusk ended the statement by saying he was a close friend of the UK and a true admirer of the Prime Minister.Additional reporting by Darren Hunt and Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.&nbsp

title: brexit news chequers agreement eu theresa may salzburg summit
story: The Prime Minister returned from the Salzburg summit last week licking her wounds after the EU immediately struck down her plans for a soft Brexit.Despite claims she would be confronted with a demand to switch to a Canada-style free trade deal approach at a Cabionter meeting yesterday afternoon, the Prime Minister&rsquos colleagues have rallied around her - at least for now.According to The Sun, one Cabinet minister said: &ldquoThere was a feeling that the PM did well on Friday with her&nbspNo.10 statement on Brexit, and she has earned some breathing space.&ldquoBut we are left with the fact that the EU has said no to Chequers, and that is a problem that is not going to go away.                EU news: Brussels sends customs warning to UK over customs shortfall                May and Trump to hold Brexit trade talks TOMORROW - WARNING to EU&ldquoSo we will have to move on from Chequers if there is no movement from Barnier in two weeks.At the weekly Cabinet meeting, the Prime Minister gave her update on her disastrous meeting with the EU, where she was told her plan was &ldquounworkable.However, with Tory Party Conference this weekend, those around Ms May have no desire to &ldquothrow the PM under the bus, Cabinet sources said.Her ultimatum will be delayed until after the party conference, at the Cabinet meeting in two weeks time.The Prime Minister is being backed by her cabinet - for now (Image: )Theresa May had her Chequers dreams dashed at the Salzburg summit last week (Image: )Ms May did not address the Salzburg summit until the end of the two-hour meeting, which was already overrunning, and told Ministers a &ldquocritical point was approaching in the negotiations.The Tory leader added: &ldquoNow is the time to hold our nerve.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab was supportive of the Prime Minister and said it was a &ldquogood, healthy discussion.He added: &ldquoThe Prime Minister made clear we are going to keep out calm and press the EU on some of the criticisms they have made.                Brexit no-deal plans REVEALED: How Britain is ready for hard Brexit                 Ministers back May's plan to end preferential treatment for EU citizenSources close to Mr Hunt said he has &ldquointellectual sympathy with a Canada-style free trade deal (Image: )&ldquoBut also to be clear that there are no credible alternatives that the EU has come up with.However, Mr Raab and Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt did suggest at the weekend there are alternatives to Chequers worth considering.Despite their claims, Downing Street insists the Cabinet has always backed Chequers and &ldquothat continues to be the case.They have also said the Prime Minister is expecting the EU to produce some credible solutions or alternatives to end the deadlock by the next summit on October 18.Her spokesman said: &ldquoWe are now waiting for the EU to revolve its position.

story: Speaking on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto backed Britain in the Brexit negotiations and insisted a no deal between the UK and the EU would be catastrophic.Mr Szijjarto said: We are certain that we need a deal.&ldquoWe have to avoid a situation without a deal by all efforts.&ldquoI don't like this hard or soft categorisation of Brexit.                'Hard to see majority for that!' Benn DISMANTLES calls for new vote                Cat and dog owners face MONTHS of travel preparation under no deal He added: &ldquoOur approach is we need a fair deal that is mutually beneficial for both sides.&ldquoWe must avoid a situation where there is no free trade agreement between Britain and the EU.The foreign minister declared it would be catastrophic to revert to World Trade Organisation rules in case of a no-deal Brexit.He warned his country would be particularly affected due to its heavy reliance on British investment.HUNGARY has claimed the EU must negotiate at all cost a fair Brexit deal  (Image: Getty)Peter Szijjarto backed Britain in the Brexit negotiations and insisted a no deal needs to be avoided (Image: Getty)Splitting from Brussels bureaucrats, he also said it is unconceivable to exclude the UK from security arrangements, such as the EU&rsquos Galileo space programme.Mr Szijjarto concluded: Excluding them from these operations causes more harm on the European side than we would imagine.&ldquoA Brexit deal is a must.His remarks come less than a week after Theresa May&rsquos last blow to her Chequers agreement.                Real &lsquoBrexit prize&rsquo with Chequers alternative &ndashthink tank boss reveals                Jacob Rees Mogg says NEW plan will deliver 'Brexit PRIZE' to Britain The Head of European Council Donald Tusk rejected the proposals claiming that they &ldquowould not work (Image: Getty)At an informal summit in Salzburg, the Head of European Council Donald Tusk rejected the proposals claiming that they &ldquowould not work as they risk undermining the integrity of the single market.Mr Tusk also published a scathing social media picture taking aim at perceived cherry picking aspects of her Chequers plan.The European Council President shared a photo of himself presenting Mrs May with a cake stand in a gesture seemingly mocking Brexit.He told the Prime Minister she will have to rethink her Chequers blueprint for leaving the EU, claiming the plan will not work in its present form.Mrs May fired back at Mr Tusk's comments in her Downing Street speech on Friday  (Image: Getty)He said: &ldquoEverybody shared the view that whilst there are positive elements in the Chequers proposal, the suggested framework for economic cooperation will not work, not least because it risks undermining the single market.Mrs May fired back at the comments in her Downing Street speech on Friday and said: &ldquoYesterday Donald Tusk said our proposals would undermine the single market.&ldquoHe didn&rsquot explain how, in any detail or make any counter proposal so we are at an impasse.

title: british winemakers wine largest harvest chapel down kent alochol
story: Chapel Down (Image: Unknown)&ldquoWe are only at the start of the picking harvest but Chapel Down is expecting our biggest yield ever in part due to the summer&rsquos good weather, says Mark Harvey, the company&rsquos marketing director.&nbspAnd weather is not the only factor stoking the optimism that is sweeping the British wine industry.&nbspThe number of vineyards in Britain has doubled to more than 500 in the past 10 years and now accounts for 2,500 hectares of farmland &ndash the equivalent of 3,500 football pitches.&nbspWineGB, the body that represents all the country&rsquos wine producers, predicts that within 20 years British winemakers will be selling 40 million bottles a year.&nbsp                The grape escape: Best vineyard stays in the UKLike Chapel Down, Simpsons Wine Estate in Barham, Kent, says it is anticipating &ldquoa much larger grape harvest than expected.&nbspCo-owner Ruth Simpson says: &ldquoIn 2017 we picked three tonnes per hectare and in 2018 we are anticipating four times as much.&nbspThe mood is so buoyant that editor-in-chief of drinks trade website The-Buyer.net Richard Siddle says: &ldquoThis is the year that English wine could make the breakthrough on supermarket shelves and restaurant wine lists.&nbspHe adds: &ldquoIt will never get a better opportunity. One of the many big pluses to come out of our glorious hot summer was it provided English wine producers with what they are calling &lsquodream&rsquo conditions for grape growing.&nbsp&ldquoThis record harvest could not come at a better time as everywhere you look the English are planting vines &ndash 2.5 million of them in the last two years alone.&nbspOne of the most ambitious operators to enter the market in the past decade is former hedge fund manager Mark Driver, who &ndash with his wife Sarah, an exCity lawyer &ndash has spent millions creating a 650-acre vineyard in the South Downs of Sussex.&nbspTheir Rathfinny Wine Estate launched its first sparkling wine in June and the Drivers expect to be producing almost a million bottles a year by 2025.&nbspThey have also latched on to a trend to combine winemaking with tourism.&nbspMark Driver (Image: Bloomberg via Getty Images)Last year 40,000 people went on tours of the estate and it recently opened its Tasting Room restaurant.&nbsp&ldquoThe English wine industry is on a roll, says Siddle.&nbsp&ldquoBut it&rsquos one thing putting vines in the ground and making record levels of wine. You still need people to buy it.&nbsp&ldquoIn the past when English wine has enjoyed record harvests it has been with the caveat that it will all soon sell out and you will be lucky to get your hands on a bottle. But now we are getting the critical mass where they can be on the shelf of your supermarket or wine store all year round.&nbspChapel Down, whose wines are sold at Waitrose, Sainsbury&rsquos, Tesco and Marks &amp Spencer, is a good example of this.&nbspA wine supplier to 10 Downing Street it is also supported by chefs Gordon Ramsay and Jamie Oliver. And it is not alone.&nbsp&ldquoThere are now hundreds of top restaurants with at least one or two English wines on the list, says Siddle.&nbspWhy you must have bottle to start your own vineyardUK heatwave to spark vintage year for British wines as vineyards' p...No deal Brexit no problem for British wine as heatwave helps producers&ldquoThey are not just listing them to make you feel good, they are doing so because an increasing number of English wine producers are making world-class wines.&nbspTake Norfolk&rsquos Winbirri Vineyards. Last year its Bacchus 2015 won the Decanter award for best single-grape white wine in the world.&nbspMany English vineyards also excel in producing sparkling vintages and in this sector they are giving the big Champagne houses a run for their money.&nbspIndeed the success of English sparkling wines has led French Champagne estates such as Taittinger to invest in vineyards in the South of England.&nbspVranken-Pommery, which has a partnership with Hampshire&rsquos Hattingley Valley vineyard, became the first of the big Champagne estates to release an English sparkling wine earlier this year.

story: Angela Rayner has been brutally grilled by BBC Newsnight host Evan Davis  (Image: BBC)Reporting from the Labour Party Conference in Liverpool, the flagship show&rsquos presenter interviewed the Shadow Secretary of State for Education and pinpointed to her the state of disorder Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos party is currently in.After asking Mrs Rayners questions about Labour&rsquos fresh vows to rein in academies and scrap free school, Mr Davis quizzed the political on Labour&rsquos Brexit stance, an area which is &ldquomuch more confusing.He said: &ldquoYou have had plenty of time to think about Brexit as a party.&ldquoYet today I am still confused about your approach to the potential for another vote on the issue when a deal or no deal is struck. title: BBC Weather forecast UK today news Met Office forecast latest update cold temperature
story: BBC Weather have forecast temperatures are on track to dip below freezing in some areas of the country on Tuesday morning as temperatures take a more autumnal twist.The country is set to be split in two as southern areas take the bear the brunt of the lowering thermometers while Scotland and the northwest remain milder thanks to the extra cloud.BBC Weather meteorologist Ben Rich said: We started today with a real autumn chill, in fact, a touch of frost in places and for some those temperatures are really dipping away again, particularly in the south. Further north, something a little bit milder because we are bringing some extra cloud in from the Atlantic, with that a strengthening breeze.The temperature profile shows the pale green colour across much of England Wales, also into the southeast of Scotland. In these areas, temperatures will go down into single digits, even in the big towns and cities. Out in the countryside, some spots will get down to freezing or a little below.                BIG FREEZE WARNING: Earth braced for DECADE OF COLD WEATHEROn a more positive note, Mr Rich added the south of England and Wales will experience more sunshine as the day progresses while northern parts of the UK have been warned to brace for potentially very strong gusts of winds.Mr Rich continued: Across the northwest, not as chilly that&rsquos because we&rsquoll have areas of clouds, some outbreaks of rain, and the strengthening wind here.That&rsquos sort of weather will continue as we go through the day on Tuesday whereas further south, we may have the odd mist patch to start but then we are looking at another beautiful day, with long spells of sunshine, 17C in London &ndash quite similar to where we have been today.The white winds arrow show the steady wind, fairly light winds, but you can see for parts of northwest Wales &ndash but particularly Northern Ireland and western Scotland &ndash those winds really will be strengthening. These black arrows are the wind gusts which could reach 50 to maybe 60-65 mph.BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures will deep considerably on Tuesday (Image: BBC WEATHER)Norwich, where it will be just 2C, is expected to be the coldest area in Britain whereas London, Birmingham and Belfast are expected to experience 6C temperatures in the morning.&nbspSome mist and fog will be possible on Tuesday morning, although it should clear away quite quickly to make way for a band of high pressure.But Met Office forecasters have said temperatures could rocket to the mid-20s this week after an early start characterised by intense rain and frosty temperatures.According to the Met Office long-range forecast, this Autumn could see long spells of settled and sunny weather and temperatures should improve throughout the week.The Met Office reported: &ldquoThrough the rest of September the weather should stay largely settled with long spells of sunshine and generally light winds.For October, settled and drier conditions are likely to dominate across many parts of the UK during the beginning of this period.

title: northern rail strikes august september routes
story: As Northern insists it is trying to modernise its services, union members have planned to extend walk-outs into October. Heres what we know...Members of the RMT union began the first of many 24 hour strikes on August 25, and again on September 1, 8, 15 and September 22.Northern Rail has confirmed RMT trade union members will also strike on September 29 as well as October 6, 13 and 20.Northern said it would operate about 30 per cent of its usual services.The operator has listed routes which will be affected on its website.Or keep up to date via social media on Twitter @northernassist or FacebookVery few of its trains will run before 9am and after 6pm, a spokesperson warned.Northern advises that Sunday will also see planned cancellations on a small minority of routes, primarily in the north west, and customers should check up to the last minute before travelling.Northern issued a response to RMTs announcement of three further days of strike action on consecutive Saturdays on 6, 13 and 20 October.Richard Allan, Deputy Managing Director, Northern, said: “Northern invited RMT to ACAS talks and agreed to discuss the three options RMT had suggested beforehand on the role of the on-board member of staff.  Northern was prepared to talk about the RMTs options.However, RMT unilaterally changed the basis of what they were prepared to talk about.This is despite the fact that they have reached agreements on similar terms elsewhere in the industry.RMT then called yet more strike action which will only cause further unnecessary dficulty for customers.Northern remains ready to talk about the options and calls on RMT to cancel strike action and  to the talks.Northern is getting on with the important job of modernising local rail for customers with new trains, better stations and more services.It remains willing to involve RMT in that positive future for colleagues and customers. But progress can only be achieved through talking.Walkouts have also occurred on other operators such as Southern, Merseyrail, Greater Anglia and South Western Railway over the year.Rail union RMT has accused Northern of refusing point blank to engage in serious and meaningful talks.But the union claimed driver-only operation was being extended in the name of increased profits.In a statement, Northern said: We maintain that talking costs nothing, whilst strike action causes inconvenience to customers and damages the case for long-term investment in rail.In previous strikes, Northern said almost 1,400 trains would run on each day of industrial action — around half the usual number.Mick Cash, RMT general secretary, said: Members have been in dispute for well over a year now in a battle to put public safety before private profit and we are angry and frustrated that a genuine opportunity to reach an agreement has been kicked back by the company.Northern Rail want to run nearly half a million trains a year without a safety critical guard on board in a move that would wreck both safety and access ‎to services.

title: theresa may brexit james forsyth
story: Instead, she is trying to shock the EU into engaging with it by telling them she really is serious about no deal.This is a mighty gamble. The EU know this Government didn’t start properly planning for no deal until this summer.Senior figures there believe the UK will back down rather than go down a route it is so ill-prepared for.So Mrs May is trying to, publicly, burn her boats on the beach.To show that she can’t accept membership of the European Economic Area and the customs union, which would leave the UK as essentially a non-voting member of the EU, or the current Irish backstop, which would see Northern Ireland kept in the EU’s customs union even as the rest of the UK leaves it.One Downing Street source tells me all European leaders say they want an agreement.But a deal isn’t compatible with their Irish backstop proposal. So they’ll have to choose.If the EU doesn’t show any sign of moving in the next fortnight, Mrs May will come under real pressure to change tack from Chequers from her own Cabinet.“The problem is the Cabinet ministers who backed it on the grounds that it was doable,” one Secretary of State tells me. .A growing number of Cabinet ministers think that with the EU rejecting Chequers, Mrs May should turn to a more Canada-style approach — pushing for the free trade deal the EU has repeatedly said is on offer.“There’s an opportunity amid the embarrassment,” one member of this group tells me.No10 rejects this argument, saying a Canada-style deal doesn’t solve the Irish backstop problem.But these ministers think by moving away from Chequers, the UK could create the space for a compromise on the Irish border.Another problem is how blindsided No10 was by the Salzburg snub.This will make it harder for Downing Street to persuade ministers to trust its judgment on what compromises need to be made to get a deal.For instance, Olly Robbins, the PM’s chief Europe adviser, wants us to commit to matching EU social and environmental regulations as well as product regulations.This is meant to deal with one of the EU’s objections to Chequers, that the UK could gain a competitive advantage by not following every new EU rule in these fields.But several key ministers have objections to this.They are now less likely to accept this compromise because they are far more sceptical of Robbins’ reading of the state of the negotiations.In the coming weeks, the Cabinet will become more and more assertive.They won’t all be pushing for the same thing — there are those who would prefer a customs union to a Canada-style deal — but they will demand greater input.For they nearly all worry about no deal.One Government source tells me: “We all know what no deal looks like, you can’t blunder into that.”What Mrs May must do in the coming weeks is give herself room for manoeuvre between no deal and signing up to a customs union.She is trying to do that by shocking the EU into engaging with Chequers.But  the EU won’t, then several key Cabinet ministers will push for a new approach ahead of the October EU Council.THERESA MAY has set up a small, kitchen Cabinet to consult on Brexit policy.It met in the first week of September and again on Tuesday this week.This new Cabinet grouping essentially replaces the Brexit inner Cabinet.Mrs May cooled on this Brexit inner Cabinet, which was designed to be balanced between those who campaigned for Brexit and those who had backed Remain, after it objected to her preferred customs plan.I understand that Philip Hammond forcibly made the point that such a balanced committee constrained her options.Those attending this meeting include the increasingly influential David Lidington, Chancellor Philip Hammond, the Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Michael Gove, the chief whip Julian Smith and the Prime Minister’s chief of staff, Gavin Barwell, who has taken charge of the mission of selling Chequers.In Whitehall, this new group has been dubbed “The Chequers Defence Committee” because of how much of its time is taken up with working out how to sell the Prime Minister’s Brexit proposals.The first meeting included a discussion of whether, and how, ministers should respond to Boris Johnson’s broadsides against Mrs May’s plan.The discussions have also revealed something about Mrs May’s relationship with her own MPs.It was agreed that the PM would meet with a series of Labour Brexiteers – Gisela Stuart, Frank Field and Kate Hoey – in the hope that they might be able to persuade some of her MPs to back her approach.This is quite extraordinary: A PM trying to get opposition figures to persuade her own party to back her plans.CABINET will meet on Monday to discuss Britain’s post-Brexit immigration policy.This is one of the most important decisions this Government will take.So it is absurd that, on Friday lunchtime, ministers still did not have the papers for the meeting.I understand, though, that the Government’s intention is to come up with a system that does not discriminate between EU nationals and those from the rest of the world.However, the UK will be prepared to discuss immigration as part of a trade deal. But this arrangement will not be free movement.Earlier this month, Mrs May told her closest Cabinet colleagues that this is one of the issues she is determined not to compromise on.What is required is an immigration system that encourages the best and the brightest to come here and ensures this country has the workers it needs.I UNDERSTAND there was a plan for Jeremy Corbyn to attend today’s Liverpool match against Southampton ahead of Labour’s conference in the city.But the club didn’t want him on the pitch, so Corbyn won’t get to score at the Kop end.Labour deny that there was any plan for Corbyn to go on to the pitch.IF No10 didn’t have enough to worry about ahead of Tory conference, there is the issue of Theresa May’s voice.She can ill afford a repeat of last year, when it kept giving out during the speech.In an attempt to prevent this from happening, her schedule will be pared right back. Mrs May will do some events designed to encourage more women into politics.But Cabinet Ministers will fill in for her at the ious regional receptions to try to save her voice.Mrs May’s voice isn’t No10’s only concern.One Cabinet minister tells me: “They are completely paranoid she is going to get slow hand-clapped.”This fear strikes me as misplaced.Activists who remember the agony of last year’s conference speech will give her credit for standing up and doing it all over again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says theresa may freedom brexit
story: It was blindingly obvious then that Brussels would not negotiate in good faith. On Thursday they proved it, with their squalid ambush and the infantile taunting online.Mrs May has always treated EU leaders with respect. But these bullying egomaniacs, these swaggering posers in designer suits, lack the common decency to respect Britain, our Prime Minister and our democratic choice.So yesterday, on behalf of her position and the nation, she bit back. It was the best speech of her le. And her ­arguments were as unassailable as her welcome new tone was hostile.We CANNOT remain part of the EU’s institutions — and make a mockery of the referendum verdict. We WILL NOT split the UK. We WILL NOT annul the Brexit vote because they don’t like it.We CANNOT keep making sacrices and proposing solutions only for Brussels to reject them without any sensible counter offer. That’s not a negotiation.So, as Mrs May says, it’s stalemate. If, as The Sun expects, their response is more of the same, she should tell them this: “Here’s one final offer... not Chequers, but a simple free trade deal, plus security co-operation, that respects our referendum and your principles.“And since Michel Barnier now accepts that technology CAN police borders, let’s use it between Northern Ireland and Ireland.” If they spurn that, we’ll know they aren’t serious.We can leave with no deal, bank our £39billion orce payment and mitigate short-term damage by slashing taxes.We will lure businesses and talent from the continent and embrace those already here, as Mrs May has promised.And we will be free from the clutches of the Brussels club and the posturing pygmies running it.IS anyone more delusional or dishonest than the laughably-named People’s Vote campaign?These Remainiac losers pretend a second referendum is in the nation’s interests when it plainly only serves theirs.To get their way they would risk hideous disorder and the annihilation of trust in democracy. And they are utterly deluded about their chances of victory.Almost all Leavers would vote the same way, alongside many ex-Remainers who know the first vote must be honoured and now see the EU for what it truly is, especially after Thursday.But even  Remain won, why should anyone respect THEIR victory?It would never be sustainable. The fury at an EU which bullied us into a rerun would never subside. Nor would the rage at Remain diehards who ­colluded with Brussels to bring it about.The genie is out of the bottle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may insulted eu salzburg opinion
story: For some time I have said that was a very poor plan because the UK would have become rule takers, which was not what we voted for.However, nothing else shows the British people why we need to leave the EU as soon as possible than the dictatorial, pompous and hectoring tone of the unelected EU Council president Donald Tusk and the “Polly Pocket” Napoleon, President Macron of France, as they gleefully stuck the boot into Theresa May.The Prime Minister in reply made a statement on Friday setting out her new demands. The first that the Prime Minister was clearly angered by their treatment of her.Regardless of their views on Chequers, she has the right to believe that as the UK has always treated the EU with respect, so EU leaders should show the UK the same respect in .Second is what I and others have been saying, that the best and most workable relationship after we leave is one based on a comprehensive free trade agreement between the UK and the EU.However,  we are to reach such an agreement, the EU must recognise that they will have to get rid of the demands for a Northern Irish border backstop, which blocks such a deal.The EU demand that either the UK as a whole stay in the Customs Union or that Northern Ireland is separated from the UK by a customs border is unacceptable and would harm our Union.In fact, a recent publication by two ex-Secretaries of State for Northern Ireland shows that there does not need to be a “hard” border with checkpoints or gates, and instead we could have a practical solution where goods flow freely between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In fact, such a system should be employed at all our borders around the UK, as this would greatly reduce the likelihood of customs problems at ports from Zeebrugge to Calais.So after months of manoeuvring, and poor advice from advisers in No10, now the choice is at least — and at last — crystal clear.The UK wants a comprehensive trade deal with the EU but they need to cease demands about the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.Failing that, the UK will leave under terms which govern trade between nations around the world.No trade deal is better than a bad trade deal, so the ball is firmly in the EU’s court.By Priti Patel, Tory former Cabinet ministerOUTRAGEOUS, insulting and immature sums up the EU’s appalling behaviour to the UK and to our Prime Minister.These shenanigans from an out-of-touch EU elite serve to demonstrate why Britain was right to vote leave.Who wants to remain in a club where its senior unelected figures mock our great and proud country and shamefully ambush our PM?Not only has Britain bankrolled the EU for the past 45 years, the freedoms and liberties enjoyed by the Continent have been secured by our Armed Forces and the sacrices Britain made in two world wars.While we want to maintain strong, friendly and cordial relations with our friends and partners in Europe, Donald Tusk belittles the PM on social media and President Macron brands those who back Brexit as “liars”.Macron’s undiplomatic comments are an insult not only to the 17.4million people who backed Brexit but to the entire country.Their aim is simple. To reverse the result of the referendum and put Brussels back in charge.The British people deserve better than the EU humiliating and insulting us.We are a proud nation and will not stand for a Government that surrenders to unreasonable demands from Europe’s unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats. This Government has already gone too far, with Chequers offering the EU control over large parts of our law-making.The sad fact about the position the Government is now in is that it was advised to “chuck Chequers” and pursue an alternative course of free and open trade.However, this is not the moment to cower and compromise further.Salzburg should mark the moment when we decide as a country to press ahead with taking back full control over our destiny.Our generous overtures of a £40billion orce payment, remaining an EU rule taker and compromise have been spurned and the EU is resorting to insults.So it’s time the Government realised this and “got real” on Brexit.Britain must take back control of these negotiations and send the EU a signal it will understand loud and clear.We must take the £40billion off the table and remind the EU there are serious consequences to their appalling behaviour and this will hit them hard.If they want to negotiate then we should offer them a take-it-or-leave-it, Canada-plus-style free trade deal, which is an economic prize for the UK and our trading partners.We leave the EU in six months and instead of wasting time accommodating its belligerent attitude, now is the time to unite the nation, believe in Britain and let the EU know that Brexit really does mean Brexit. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tom jones vanished university freshers week called pal
story: Tom Jones was last seen five days ago in Worcester city centre as he made his way back to student accommodation at around 3am.His parents, Ian Jones and his we Vicki, had spoken to their son after the night out and said he was back at halls and safe.But they raised the alarm the next day after struggling to get hold of Tom, who is due to start his studies in Primary Education at Worcester University.And now Harley Hetherington, who has known the missing teen since they were kids, said he was fine right up until the point he went missing.Harley said: I saw him in the Velvet nightclub and he seemed absolutely fine. He was behaving normally and didnt seemed intoxicated at all.He added: Tom had phoned his mum and then his new flatmate to tell him he was two minutes away from home before he disappeared.Nobody can quite understand how its happened.He was quite close to getting home safe and had told people he was fine right up until the point he went missing.It has also been revealed Tom sent pals a picture on Snapchat moments before vanishing.Harley, 18, said: He was seen  in the nightclub but we dont know  he was alone or not.We know he went to McDonalds afterwards for from food and then he walked home.He sent the Snapchat image and then called his flatmates later to say he was two minutes from home.The last known image is the Snapchat post. We dont know who the two people arrested on suspicion of murder are.  We are all devastated and praying for good news.We are all trying to stick together both physically and mentally. No-one can understand whats happened.Two men, both aged 20, arrested in connection with the police investigation into his disappearance have now been released and face no further action.Tom, who is originally from Bromsgrove, had arrived in Worcester last weekend.His parents are desperately urging anyone who saw him between 3.30am and 4.30am on Wednesday to contact police.Dad Ian said: We last spoke to Tom on the phone at just after 3am, he told us he was already back home and was safe.My we, Vicki, then text him at 8.45am as we knew he had lectures and we wanted to check in with him.But we didn’t get a response and as hours passed we started to worry as he wasn’t answering our calls or texts.We are all so worried, it has been the most distressing two days of our lives and it’s completely out of character for Tom.He’s a lovely lad, happy go lucky and loves playing football, we just want him back home. If anyone knows anything about where he is please get in touch. Any information is useful.Worcester University has laid on counselling for students in the wake of Toms disappearance.Free taxis are also being laid on so students can get back to their digs safely from nights out in the city centre.Fresher Lauren Brown, 18, said: The university has been great.Its the last thing you want during your first days at uni but they have been good.The support is there for us  we need it. Everyone is just really concerned.Sammy Taylor, 18, was at the Velvet nightclub at the same time as Tom.She told how there was barely room to move inside the club as freshers converged on Tuesday night.The student added: I was out that night. It was rammed in there, there was a queue out of the door and down the street.Its hard to believe someone could go for a night out and not come home. Tom has been described as white, 5ft 5ins, slim, with short mousy brown hair and greyish green coloured eyes.He was wearing pale coloured jeans, a navy blue woolen zip-up Lacoste top, and green shoes at the time of his disappearance.Det Insp James Bayliss from West Mercia Police said: The investigation into the disappearance of Thomas remains a priority and we are keeping an open mind as to the circumstances surrounding Thomass disappearance.This remains a missing person enquiry.I would like to thank the public of Worcester for their support and concern, the community response has been exceptional.We continue to actively search the area and I would reiterate that anyone with any information should contact the police as soon as possible.Anyone with any information is asked to call West Mercia Police on 101 quoting incident number 431s of 19 September.

title: jezza may snap election brexit

story: Rumours of a snap election in November, just four months before we leave the EU, are deeply concerning.Not only does it give the impression of a Government in chaos, it would cost Britain valuable negotiating time.Decision time is quickly approaching for Theresa May.“Brexit means Brexit” will soon need flesh added to the bones: the Chequers compromise or the more ambitious — but more dficult to deliver — model presented by free traders today.And far from pondering her domestic strength, she should focus on flexing her muscles with Brussels.Above all, it means reminding that unconvincing Napoleon tribute act Emmanuel Macron and the tight-fisted Angela Merkel that we’re perfectly happy to break free without paying a penny of our £39billion “exit deal”.They must know that asking their own increasingly Eurosceptic voters to fill the hole left by our departure could bring down the whole house of cards.And keeping that cash here would pay for plenty of tax cuts, making the UK even more competitive on a global stage.It’s time to get tough. title: john mcdonnell labour party conference speech
story: John McDonnell’s astonishing plans for a Socialist revolution triggered fears of an unprecedented exodus by business chiefs.Labour plans to fire dozens of senior businessmen from nationalised companies  the party wins power.The Shadow Chancellor revealed the bosses of utility firms would be sacked and forced to reapply for their jobs - at a much lower salary.The announcement came as Jeremy Corbyn’s right-hand man announced a string of plans for the British economy which would take the country back to the 1970s.The Shadow Chancellor confirmed that Labour wants to forcibly take over the UK’s water companies and take them into the hands of the state.  Experts claim that renationalising the water industry would cost £90billion.During the hardline address to Labours party conference in Liverpool, Mr McDonnell also:NOTHING is faster than light. Except, maybe, the rate at which jobs would be destroyed by Labour’s insane Marxist ­programme unleashed yesterday.At the very moment, post-Brexit, when we will need to maximise investment and cut costs for job-creating businesses, Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell would declare war on them.His measures to interfere in, steal from or close private firms would be a bullet to the heart of the economy. What sane foreign business would come here or invest here? What sane firm, entrepreneur or inidual talent would stay?His pointless mass renationalisation programme would require debts dwarfing those we have spent nine years painfully reducing. The job-creating miracle since 2010 would be reversed.McDonnell no longer even pretends to be moderate. His is a deranged experiment on the world’s fth-biggest economy. A full-on hard-left revolution. Ask starving Venezuelans how they pan out.But the reason it cuts through is a lack of Tory ideas. McDonnell’s medicine is poison. So what’s Chancellor Philip Hammond’s remedy for our problems?Taxing your fizzy drink at McDonald’s.Mr McDonnell said: “Water bills have risen 40 per cent in real terms since privatisation.“Water companies receive more in tax credits than they pay in tax. Each day enough water to meet the needs of 20million people is lost due to leakages.“With figures like that, we can’t afford not to take them back.”In the small print published by Labour today, the party confirmed that all senior figures at the firms will be put out of a job.They said: “All staff will transfer in the same roles, except for senior executives and directors, whose posts will be re-advertised on dramatically reduced salaries capped by our 20:1 pay ratio policy.”In a chilling warning, Mr McDonnell said that under Labour, the full weight of the Treasury would be used to “take on any vested interests that try to thwart the will of the people”.Michael Roberts, the head of Water UK, said in response: “To replace managers who have decades of experience in running successful water companies, and put much needed investment at risk by handing the industry over to politicians, risks years of chaos in an essential public service.”Mr McDonnell used his speech to officially unveil plans to force all large companies to transfer a tenth of their shares into a fund controlled by employees.He said: We will legislate for large companies to transfer shares into an Inclusive Ownership Fund. The shares will be held and managed collectively by the workers.The shareholding will give workers the same rights as other shareholders to have a say over the direction of their company.And idend payments will be made directly to the workers from the fund. Payments could be up to £500 a year.Business groups have warned that the plan could devastate the economy by slashing the value of companies and discouraging them from investing in improved productivity.Adam Marshall of the British Chambers of Commerce said: Let no one be fooled, Labour’s proposals are both a tax grab and an unprecedented overreach into the way many of our businesses are run and will raise serious concerns.At a time of peak Brexit uncertainty, when Labour should be setting out how it will support business confidence and investment, it is announcing policies that would deliver the exact opposite.“The call for wholesale nationalisation could put investment in a deep freeze at precisely the time we want to be encouraging investment in the economy.Economists likened the vow to the Socialist policies of late Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez.And Matt Kilcoyne of the Adam Smith Institute blasted: The Chavez-style commitment to readvertise jobs at utility firms taken back into state control will make the roles political and take people with years of experience and track records of success away from where theyre most needed.CBI head Carolyn Fairbairn said: “Take steps like this and investment will flee our country and the outcome will be one that reduces pay in people’s pockets.”Chancellor Philip Hammond said: “Labour’s plan to put politicians in charge of crucial industries means there would be nowhere to turn when things go wrong.Mr McDonnell opened his speech by suggesting that the anti-Semitism crisis which has gripped Labour in recent months is an attempt to smear Mr Corbyn.He said: They’ve attacked my friend and they’ve attacked him because he stands up for the ideals and beliefs that we all have.I just want to say Jeremy how proud I am of you for the courage and dignity you have shown.

title: otzi mystery tattoos deciphered
story: Otzi, a frozen 5,300-year-old man, was found in 1991 in a glacier in the Alps between what is now Austria and Italy.Since the discovery, Otzi has been examined by multiple teams of scientists, with new chest tattoos among the more recent discoveries.Some now believe that he may have benefited from a form of prehistoric healthcare after they found tattoo markings they claim are actually acupuncture wounds on his remains.Scientists have previously organised these tattoos into 19 dferent groups, each of which form a set of horizontal or vertical lines.According to Discover Magazine, they cluster around joints and the lower back - where Otzi suffered from degeneration.However, researchers who put forth the acupuncture claim still do not know  the tattoos demarcated the areas for acupuncture treatment, or  they were the treatment itself.It also still remains a theory, as they have noted he had markings across his chest where he suffered no known ailments.Meanwhile, according to Albert Zink of the Institute for Mummy Research in Bolzano, new findings show that healthcare at the time of the iceman was surprisingly well developed.Bolzano scientists found that Otzi, who lived to 40 or 50 years of age, probably had some chronic health problems.A careful study of his remains showed that his teeth were carious, he suffered with stomach ulcers, his joints were worn out and his blood vessels were calcied.Zink claims that Otzi was treated for his medical conditions by prehistoric doctors.Researchers found traces of birch polypore fungi in Otzis belongings which have anti-inflammatory and antibiotic properties.They also found bracken which was used to combat intestinal parasites.Upon a more careful study of Otzis body, Zink and his colleagues discovered that the icemans skin was actually covered with 61 tattoos.To make the tattoos, coal dust was rubbed into small wounds similar to the insertion of acupuncture needles, which according to Zink is a time-consuming and skillful endeavour.Earlier this year, experts found undisputed proof that Otzi died from an arrow injury.

story: The UK has been lashed by heavy rain and monster winds after Storm Ali and Storm Bronagh hit bringing a danger to le warning.But the weather looks set to do a U-turn this week with temperatures beginning to climb to 23C by Thursday - making it hotter than Athens.The south, Wales and the Midlands will see the best of the weather with glorious sunshine as Brits enjoy an Indian Summer.But the north will see more wind and outbreaks of rain through the week and cloudier skies - although temperatures will still be warmer than the recent chillier conditions.And sunshine is predicted for most the UK this weekend after last Saturday and Sunday were washed out by the two named storms.The Met Office said: A north-south split will develop through the middle of the week, becoming cloudier and windy with some rain in the North. but remaining settled, dry and mostly sunny in the South.Through the rest of September the weather should stay largely settled with long spells of sunshine and generally light winds.For October, settled and drier conditions are likely to dominate across many parts of the UK during the beginning of this period.Storm Ali last week sent Britain grinding to a halt with 100mph winds grounding planes, closing roads and leaving more than 170,000 people without power.Swiss tourist Elvira Ferraii, died after the caravan she was sleeping in was blown off a clf near Clden in Co Galway.And an engineer, aged in his 20s, was then killed by a falling tree in Slieve Gullion Forest Park in Newry, Northern Ireland.A woman in Cheshire was seriously injured when a tree fell on to her car in the high winds – fire crews eventually freed the woman before she was taken to hospital by air ambulance.As the clean up began, Storm Bronagh then slammed into the UK with strong winds and heavy rain causing travel chaos.

title: cure alzheimer world first
story: In research being hailed as a world first, they aim to target toxic particles that trigger the brain disease.Their work could lead to tests on new drug treatments by 2020.Experts at Cambridge University and from Sweden have identied these particles as the prime cause of Alzheimer’s and worked out a formula for targeting them.Until now, drugs have tackled Alzheimer’s symptoms and attempts to discover medicines to prevent or slow it have failed.But in findings published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Cambridge researcher Prof Michele Vendruscolo says: “We’ve devised the first strategy to go after the cause.“The hope is that new drugs can be developed.”A healthy brain has a quality control system that gets rid of any excessive amounts of these proteins.In Alzheimer’s, proteins called oligomers which usually help brain cells to  normally “go rogue” by forming clumps that kill healthy nerve cells.A separate study, by the University Hospital of Tubingen in Germany,  has shown that two and half hours a week of exercise can delay the effects of Alzheimer’s. title: theresa may chequers plan two week progress window
story: The Tory top table ducked out of a confrontation with the PM over last week’s Salzburg summit debacle  during their weekly meeting  yesterday.Brexiteers claimed Mrs May would be ambushed with an ultimatum to switch to asking for a Canada-style free trade deal.But every minister stayed silent during her update on how EU leaders ripped up her softer  plan in front of her at the Austrian summit.There was no appetite to “throw the PM under the bus” just six days before the start of the Tories’ annual conference, Cabinet sources said.Instead,  the revolt will take place at the first Cabinet meeting afterwards —  Brussels still hasn’t ceded signicant ground.One Cabinet minister told The Sun: “There was a feeling  that the PM did well on Friday with her No10 statement on Brexit, and she has earned some breathing space.“But we are still left with the fact that the EU has said no to Chequers, and that is a problem that is not going to go away. So we will have to move on from Chequers  there is no movement from Barnier in two weeks.”Mrs May  left the Salzburg update to the very end of the  two-hour meeting, which had already overrun.One minister said: “We just wanted to get out by then.”During her pitch, Mrs May told them that “a critical point” was always going to come in the negotiations. But she implored: “Now is the time to hold our nerve”.The PM was backed by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab straight after the meeting, who dubbed it “a good, healthy discussion”.He added: “The Prime Minister made clear we are going to keep our calm and press the EU on some of the criticisms  they have made. But also to be clear that there are no credible alternatives  the EU has come up with.”Over the weekend, Mr Raab joined Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt to cast doubt on the Chequers plan by suggesting there are alternatives." data-credit="" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/b5.jpg?strip=all&ampw=817" height="519" width="817"/4Over the weekend, Mr Raab joined Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt to cast doubt on the Chequers plan by suggesting there are alternativesSources close to Mr Hunt yesterday said he has “intellectual sympathy” with a Canada-style free trade deal.But No10 insists the Cabinet has always fully backed Chequers “and that continues to be the case”.Downing Street also made it clear that the PM was expecting the EU to come up with a solution to the deadlock by the next  summit on October 18.Her official spokesman said: “We are now waiting for the EU to evolve its position.”TWO thirds of Brexit voters just want to leave the EU and do not care how.A poll found 66 per cent who backed Leave are “not interested in the details and just want those responsible to get on with it”.The ORB poll of 2,000 found 82 per cent  are “fed up with some pro-Brexit and pro-Remain politicians claiming they speak for everyone who voted in the referendum”.The poll was commissioned by the Brexit Delivery Group, Tory backbenchers pushing for a softer Brexit.Leader Simon Hart said: “This shows voters are much more realistic and pragmatic than MPs. It’s time to put ideology to one side and listen.”But  pro-EU Tory MPs  stepped up their calls for an alternative Brexit plan at the same time as hardline Brexiteer Tories did. Mrs May’s former policy chief George Freeman joined ex-minister Nick Boles to call for Britain to be part of the European Free Trade association  so it can keep single market access.Mr Freeman said: “There’s a Brexit solution waiting on the shelf. We should take it.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: from the football terraces to the tower blocks fascinating new pictures capture the defiant spirit of young skinheads from their rise in the 1960s
story: The very first skinheads were working class youths from London who couldnt be further removed from the hippys peace and love movement of the mid to late 1960s.Instead they were drawn towards outsider subcultures, incorporating elements of Caribbean music and fashion, especially from the Jamaican rude boys.The skinhead subculture is said to have first emerged in London in the late-1960s, when a split developed among gangs of mods.Finding more interest in music than the fashion-obsessed mod subculture, the first skins adopted a unorm of work boots, short jeans and, of course, close-cropped hair.Hardcore skins at the time used to brag that long hair just got in the way during street fights - which were often against the mods they used to run with.By 1969/1970 - when some of these amazing photos were taken -  the movement had reached its peak and quickly spread across the rest of Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
