title: special treatment of eu citizens to end
story: Theresa May’s top table gave its backing to a “global” new immigration system that will treat all nationalities the same.The decision is a major victory for Home Secretary Sajid Javid, who has waged a bitter battle against other ministries such as the Treasury to halt preferential treatment for EU citizens and finally end free movement.Also under Mr Javid’s blueprint, low skilled migration will be cut and new arrivals with talent will increase in a bid to boost the economy’s longterm productivity problems.The plan has major implications for the Brexit negotiations, as special access to Britain can now no longer be able to traded away for a better trade deal with Brussels now that Cabinet has signed it off.Some limited exceptions to the principle will be built into the new system to protect the economy. Lower skilled workers will be granted entry in areas where there are serious labour market shortages that have not been able to be filled from the domestic market – such as in hospitality and construction.The Cabinet victory for Mr Javid was dubbed “a slam dunk” last night, after he won earlier support from the PM for it. Chancellor Philip Hammond made a plea for the Cabinet to give the new system more thought before they made a decision, but he was rebuffed.Business Secretary Greg Clark also insisted on the need to be flexible with Brussels during a long discussion yesterday afternoon.But a Cabinet source said: “There was a little bit of grumbling from the usual suspects, Philip and Greg, but they folded pretty quickly. It was a very well executed operation by Sajid, as he had all the facts on his side.”Mr Javid’s plan was boosted by a presentation to Cabinet yesterday by the chair of the independent Migration Advisory Committee, Professor Alan Manning. The LSE professor repeated his findings from a landmark, year-long report last week that there was little need for low skilled immigration to the UK.Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey was also said to have taken a dig at Mr Hammond during the No10 meeting.The Sun was told that passionate Brexiteer Ms McVey said to the table: “We’re told by some people that we’re going to have a recession when we leave, and at the same time that we need mass immigration to keep the economy afloat. They can’t both be correct”.Downing Street is keeping the Cabinet’s formal conclusions under wraps so that she can unveil them in her speech to Tory conference next week.But in a strong hint at what we decided, a No10 spokesman said last night: “Cabinet today received a presentation from Migration Advisory Committee chairman Professor Alan Manning.“Cabinet was told by Professor Manning that the MAC was recommending that, in the post-Brexit immigration system, EEA and non-EEA nationals should be part of one universal system.“A key conclusion was that high skilled migration is of greater economic benefit than lower skilled migration, and as such the MAC recommended that the new system should make it easier for higher skilled than lower skilled workers to come to the UK.“The Cabinet agreed that, once free movement is brought to an end, the Government will be able to introduce a new system which works in the best interests of the United Kingdom – including by helping to boost productivity.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: scrabble 300 new words official dictionary
story: And it is not just obscure terms allowed in – the long-awaited validation of ‘OK’ has been revealed.Scrabble fans can rejoice after 300 new worlds have been added to its official dictionaryNew word “bizjet”, a small business plane, is worth up to 120 points as an opening play.Merriam-Webster has released the latest and sixth edition of The Official Scrabble Players Dictionary, four years after the last revamp.The company published the first official Scrabble dictionary in 1976. Until then, the games rules allowed any dictionary to be consulted by players.Here, Ben Leo picks out more of the latest additions to help you score.Twerking could earn Miley Cyrus 12 points next time shes reminiscing with Robin Thicke over a game of ScrabbleThe official version of the dictionary is now updated every four to eight years.Peter Sokolowski, editor at large at Merriam-Webster said: “OK is something Scrabble players have been waiting for, for a long time.“Basically two and three-letter words are the leblood of the game.”The Merriam-Webster version is typically used by American players of the board game, with UK publisher Collins putting out a Brit-focused dictionary. This has not been updated since 2015.ARANCINI – Deep-fried risotto balls.AQUAFABA – Water which pulses or seeds have been cooked in.BEATDOWN – A violent physical beating.BIBIMBAP – Korean rice dish.BOKEH – Out-of-focus area of a picture.BOTNET – Network of computers infected with viruses.COTIJA –Hard dry Mexican cheese.EMOJI – Digital cartoon faces, pictures and symbols.EW – To express disgust or taste.FACEPALM – Act of putting head in one’s palm out of frustration.FROWNY – To contract the eyebrows as an expression of disapproval.HIVEMIND – Group thinking.MACARON – Small round cake.NUBBER – In baseball, a batted ball that does not travel very far.OK – Affirmation. Yes or understood.PUGGLE – Cross-breed of Beagle and Pug dogs.QAPIK – Azerbaijan currency unit.SCHNEID – German phrase for sports’ team losing streak.SHEEPLE – People who follow the crowd like sheep.SRIRACHA – Spicy red Asian sauce.TWERK – Bum-wiggling dance.WAYBACK – Sometime in the past.YOWZA – Used to indicate surprise.ZEN – Feeling of calm, through Buddhist meditation.ZOMBOID – Gormless person who may as well be dead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boa constrictor couple attic nuneaton
story: Steve Hope tried to go into his loft to look for a book but screamed out after the reptile nearly hit his head and knocked him to the floor.His terried we Annette heard him swear and shout “It’s a snake” and she immediately ran up to stairs to see what had happened in Nuneaton, Warks.Steve told Coventry Live: “I had opened the hatch and it just fell out, it almost hit my head.“At first I thought it was one of those door draft excluders, then I realised it was a snake.”They then called 999 after leaving messages with the local wildle sanctuary and vet surgeries.Annette added: “I said we had a snake in the house that wasn’t ours and there was a pregnant pause before they said ‘Ok, right’. I don’t think they believed me.”The snake was eventually picked up by Geoff Grewcock, owner of the Nuneaton and North Warwickshire Wildle Sanctuary.But the incident has traumatised the couple who have “not slept much” since and are refusing to go back up into the loft.Steve is still trying to work out how the large creature ended up in the attic because their house is not connected to their neighbours.He added: “It has got to have come up a pipe and somehow got inside.”

title: brit shatters land speed record after clocking up more 100mph in a garden shed
story: The bizarre road-legal motor, driven by creator Kevin Nicks, clocked 101.581mph during a record bid at Pendine Sands, Carmarthenshire.The aptly-named Fastest Shed, which boasts a 450bhp turbo-charged Audi RS4 engine, narrowly beat its own record set just last year at the beach in west Wales.Mr Nicks said he was absolutely delighted to have set another world record in his homemade £13,000 motor, just three months after its engine blew up during another race in York.Mr Nicks, from Chipping Norton, Oxfordshire, said: Its a good result. I had to start all over again when its engine blew up, and then had three months solid of mechanical problems.Because Ive had so many issues I didnt want to absolutely cane it.I went a bit steadier because I was afraid it would blow up again. But despite that Ive managed to set a new record, and Im absolutely delighted.Its not a huge gain, but its a record. Only just beating it will allow me to come back and try to beat it again.The Fastest Shed set the new record at the Straightliners Top Speed event, which was held over the weekend. Pendine Sands is one of the longest flattest beaches in the UK and has hosted numerous land speed attempts going back to the 1920s.On September 25 1924, Sir Malcolm Campbell set the record at 146.16 mph before breaking it the following year when he reached 150.75mph in his famous Blue Bird racing car. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: german president no invite ww1 anniversary
story: Field Marshal Lord Guthrie said the Remembrance Sunday ceremony was “peculiarly British” and should be for UK and Commonwealth dignitaries only.He said: “For us to have the Germans there would not be understood by a lot of people.“It’s an unnecessary thing to do.”The Sun yesterday revealed talks are under way for Germany’s Frank-Walter Steinmeier to attend the Cenotaph ceremony on November 11 in a spirit of “peace and reconciliation”.But Government aides fear the gesture could anger veterans taking part in the two-minutes’ silence and wreath-laying alongside Top Brass, Royalty and politicians.A Government Spokesperson said: “Remembrance Sunday this year coincides with the centenary of the First World War ArmisticeColonel Richard Kemp, a former Commander of British Forces in Afghanistan was also opposed to the move, saying: “One offended veteran is one too many on this hallowed day.”IT’S a big step inviting Germany’s president to the Cenotaph for Remembrance Sunday on the 100th anniversary of the end of World War One. But we’re for it.Britain lost almost one million men.But a century has passed. If now isn’t the time for reconciliation, when is? Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexiteers claim proposal supercalifragilisticbrexpialidocious
story: Turning the screw on the PM, David Davis and Jacob Rees-Mogg endorsed a rival blueprint for a “clean break” from Brussels.This would allow Britain to prioritise its focus on securing major new free trade deals with the likes of the US that voters were promised in the referendum, they said.And the Brexiteers stepped up their attack on Mrs May for making Britain a “supplicant” to the EU in Brexit talks with her current Chequers plan, which they said would make a US free trade deal all-but impossible.The Tory MPs spoke alongside ex-Northern Ireland Secretary and ex-Labour MP and Leave campaigner Gisela Stuart to announce the launch of an alternative Brexit plan published by the Institute of Economic Affairs in Whitehall yesterday.The y report called on ministers to seek a “basic” free trade agreement for goods and pursue “regulatory freedom and trade independence” to allow Britain to strike new free trade deals immediately.The alternative Plan A+ says grasping the opportunities of Brexit must be made the top priority - instead of being a “damage limitation exercise”.It has been compared to the kind of comprehensive free trade deal Canada has struck with the EU but Mr Rees-Mogg said the name didn’t matter - and instead rested on the PM changing her approach. He also claimed the EU had already offered this more basic approach to a new trade deal.Speaking at the alternative plan’s launch, Mr Rees-Mogg said: “So much of what we hear about these negotiations has been about managing decline, has been about how you have the least bad Brexit, this is about how you can have a fantastic Brexit that sets us up for the next generation and ensures our prosperity.“This has been offered to us by the Commission, they have offered us the best trade deal they have ever done with any country ever in the world, so  you want to call it Canada plus, or super Canada or supercalragilisticexpialidocious Canada, that is what is being aimed and its being offered.”But the plan was overshadowed by a row over why Boris Johnson didn’t turn up at the launch. He was said to have changed his mind at the last minute.Instead he tweeted his support of the alternative plan with another dig at Mrs May.Referring to her speech on Friday calling for the EU to show Britain “respect,” Mr Johnson said of the IEA report: “This is a plan the EU would understand and respect - delivering prosperity for the UK and our European partners. I’ve no doubt it would unite MPs and the country.”But yesterday No10 poured scorn on the plans.The Prime Minister’s spokesman said: “In relation to ‘Canada plus’, no EU third country free trade agreement has ever led to a reduction in barriers to the extent that no hard border is needed, and there is no global precedent for an infrastructure-free border without substantial regulatory and customs alignment.”Referring to the EU free trade agreement  with Canada, known as CETA, Mrs May’s spokesman said: “CETA still requires third country customs controls, rules of origin requirements, risk and intelligence-led border checks.“Given a standard free trade agreement could not prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland, the EU’s position is that their proposed Northern Ireland protocol would come into effect.“So, the FTA would only apply to the Great Britain-EU relationship, with Northern Ireland effectively remaining in parts of the single market and customs union.“The PM has repeatedly set out that we must protect the economic and constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom as a whole.” GOT a story? title: british endurance cyclist mike hall inquest canberra australia
story: The 35-year-old from Harrogate was competing in the Indian Pacic Wheel Race across Australia when the tragedy unfolded on March 31, last year.The record-breaking cyclist suffered major head, spinal and abdominal injuries, the Coroners Court in the Australian Capital Territory was told.At the three-day inquest, which opened in Canberra yesterday, the court heard that the 19-year-old driver, Shegu Bobb, initially thought he had hit a kangaroo.The court was told that it was dark at the time of the crash at 6.22am and it would have been dficult for a motorist to see, according to Nine News.Hall was in second place in the coast-to-coast race, in which cyclists ride 3,400 miles from Perth to Sydney, when he as struck by the car travelling at 62mph.Counsel assisting the coroner Ken Archer said the event was known for its dficulties and likened to the Hunger Games on wheels.He said that Hall was wearing dark clothing with limited reflective qualities at the time of the collision.Mr Archer said: The bike was effectively impaled on the front of the car.The inquest was also played documentary footage of Hall racing at night in which he was visible.Mr Bobb, who was on his way to work at the time of the crash, has never been charged.The inquest heard he has suffered signicant distress and shock since the tragedy.Halls partner Anna Haslock was pictured arriving at the inquest after crowdfunding money to travel to Australia.Hall made headlines in 2012 when he broke the world record for a round the world ride, taking an incredible 91 days and 18 hours to traverse the entire globe.He had been living in Monmouthshire, South Wales, before his death.The inquest continues.

title: dame helena morrissey freedom of expression is key to diverse workplaces
story: Too often, workplaces superficially "include" people by avoiding overt bias, but at the same time encourage people to fit in, to submerge their dferences. That's the opposite of true inclusion.Welcoming erse views shows everyone that they matter, as well as helping organisations create the breakthrough moments, to solve problems, or see how to capture opportunities.The examples when I've felt really included have been when the whole decision-making process has been built around encouraging ersity of perspective. It's not been an afterthought, a self-conscious "let's make sure we've heard the woman in the room".When you reach the place where everyone wants to know what their colleagues really think because they have dferent backgrounds, experiences, qualities - and levels of seniority - you stop thinking rather articially about "identity" and have a really inclusive environment, as partners.

title: how does a second brexit referendum actually happen
story: Aside from whether or not this is a desirable outcome - of course many voters feel they have already had their say and want politicians to get on with making the best of it - could it actually happen and how?:: Is there time?We are leaving the EU on 29 March, 2019, barely six months from now.Mrs May is expected to secure an agreement - or, less likely, to deliver on her threat to walk away without one - at a special EU council meeting in November. Parliament must vote on it by early next year. Time, therefore, is short.A referendum requires legislation through Parliament.The EU Referendum Act paving the way for the vote in June 2016 took seven months to get through both Houses, after wrangling about the wording of the question, the franchise and the campaign period.Official campaigns were then designated and the actual vote was held six months after that.All the campaign groups for a second poll concede that the government would need to ask the EU for an extension to Article 50. A former EU official tells me extra time is much more likely to be granted for a second referendum than, for example, a general election, but the EU would want it "done and dusted" before the European elections in May."If it's longer than that they'll probably just want us out."The Best for Britain and People's Vote campaign groups insist that the time pressure MPs would be under would force the arrangements to progress quickly, plausibly in as little as four months after Mrs May puts her deal to Parliament.:: Why should we have it?The argument supporters make is that a lot has changed since the Vote Leave buses promised &#163350m a week, and trade secretary Liam Fox claimed a trade deal with the EU would be "the easiest deal in human history". Second vote campaigners say the Prime Minister's Chequers plan, now being attacked by Remainers as well as Leavers, was not on the ballot paper in 2016 and that therefore voters should be given the option to reconsider what is now on offer.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: iran trade and salisbury on agenda as theresa may visits un general assembly
story: It is just one item on the prime minister's agenda during the visit to New York, where she will also call for a crackdown on chemical weapons after novichok was used on the Skripals in Salisbury.When she addresses the UN Security Council on Wednesday, she will say action must be taken to prevent further use of chemical weapons and deal with previous incidents.Speaking before the visit, Mrs May said: "The red lines around the use of chemical weapons are being eroded."The Syrian regime has repeatedly used these appalling weapons against its own people while the Russian state has deployed them on UK streets."Attacks such as Salisbury and Ghouta are despicable in their own right, but they are also a threat to the wider international system.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: labour to vote against pms brexit deal
story: Sir Keir will claim the government's Brexit deal has yet to meet the Labour Party's six tests, despite the PM promising she was determined to meet them.Ahead of the debate in Liverpool, Sir Keir published a Labour dossier which he claims shows how the Tories' Brexit proposals are failing to meet the tests.Labour claims its analysis reveals the Chequers proposals currently put jobs, the economy, people's livelihoods and no hard border in Northern Ireland at risk.The Chequers deal is the cabinet agreement to ask the EU to maintain, post-Brexit, common rules and existing borderless free trade in goods and agriculture, but not services. Day three of Labour's conference will be dominated by the Brexit debate, on a motion drawn up by party fixers from 151 submitted by local parties and trade unions.The motion being debated states: "If we cannot get a general election Labour must support all options remaining on the table, including campaigning for a public vote on the terms of Brexit."That falls short of demands by pro-Remain Labour MPs who wanted a much stronger commitment to campaign for a People's Vote, but with the party badly split it gives Jeremy Corbyn room for manoeuvre.In his speech, Sir Keir is expected to say: "Just when we need a strong government, what do we see from the Tories? Division, chaos and failure."No credible plan for Brexit. No solution to prevent a hard border in Ireland. And no majority in Parliament for the Chequers proposals."A Tory civil war that has gone on for years, now threatens our future prosperity."So, I've got a message for the prime minister. 'If your party wants to tear itself apart, that's fine, but you're not taking our country with you.'"

title: uk coach operators could be barred from operating within eu in no deal brexit
story: One technical note described how UK bus and coach operators might not be able to run services within the EU  an agreement isn't reached.The document states the UK aims to join the EU's Interbus agreement as an independent member by 29 March next year, but this might be delayed. If the UK failed to join, UK operators wouldn't be able to run any services to the EU at all in the short term.Another notice revealed that producers of dozens of types of British traditional foods may be forced to apply for a new protected status from the EU  there is a no-deal Brexit.There are currently 86 agricultural, food and drink products protected under Europe's "geographical indication" schemes.These include Stilton blue cheese, Cornish clotted cream, Welsh lamb and wines and spirits.     The 86 products make up a quarter of the value of UK food and drink exports, according to the technical notices.The government said it anticipates that all the current products will continue to be protected by the EU's geographical indication schemes, which prevent them being imitated throughout the bloc.If that is not the case, producers who want to regain protection may have to reapply to the EU as a "third country" producer or take other steps such as applying for trade mark protection.Ian Wright, chief executive of the Food and Drink Federation, said: "Our politicians act as  they have six more months to conclude a withdrawal agreement.     "In fact, today's official confirmation of just how bad this scenario would be is bound to encourage businesses and shoppers to consider - now - stockpiling, buying ahead, hedging currency risk, procuring additional warehousing, relocating production to the EU, and other practical measures to secure supply.

title: labour formally announces its preparing
story: NewsLabour formally announces it's preparing to vote down Theresa May's Brexit planShadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer will give the strongest signal yet that he will order MPs to reject the deal in ParliamentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor22:30, 24 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May won't like this one bit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Labour will on Tuesday formally confirm the party is preparing to vote down Theresa May's Brexit plan.  Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer will give the strongest signal yet that he will order MPs to reject the deal in Parliament. Such a vote could spell catastrophic defeat for the Prime Minister - as it would see Labour join forces with Tory Brexiteers in the Commons. Sir Keir today declared that  that happens, on any rational view the government will then have to fall - triggering a general election. And on Tuesday, he will tell Labour's party conference in Liverpool: Some have said Labour could vote for any deal the Tories reach. Some have said we may abstain. Some have said we may support a vague deal – a ‘blind Brexit’ – that gives no detail about the terms of our future relationship.  So, let me be very clear - right here, right now: If Theresa May brings back a deal that fails our tests – and that looks increasingly likely - Labour will vote against it. No s, no buts. And  the Prime Minister thinks we’ll wave through a vague deal asking us to jump blindfolded into the unknown she can think again. You can’t meet Labour’s tests by failing to provide answers. We will vote down a blind Brexit. The comments lay down the gauntlet to Mrs May ahead of a crunch vote on her deal sometime in November. Sir Keir has set six tests  that the plan must meet before Labour will back it.  But Labour is still riven with disagreement over whether to back a second referendum on Brexit. Delegates will vote on Tuesday to keep the option of a public vote on the table - not actually back a public vote - after a six-hour meeting ended in a fudge. And a split erupted after Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell suggested any vote wouldn't have the option of remaining in the EU - only to be contradicted by Sir Keir.

title: labours plan save high street
story: NewsLabour's plan to save the high street - buses for under 25s, no ATM charges and wi-fi for allThe party's business spokeswoman Rebecca Long-Bailey also pledges to reverse bank branch and Post Office closures and create a register of landlords with empty shopsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorGraham HiscottHead of Business22:30, 24 SEP 2018Updated23:55, 24 SEP 2018NewsJeremy Corbyn's Labour is promising to revitalise our beleaguered town centres "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour will today unveil a five-point plan to save our high streets. In a victory for the Mirror’s High Street Fightback campaign, Shadow &shyBusiness &shySecretary Rebecca Long-Bailey will pledge to end the crisis. The major policy announcement comes after we laid bare the scale of decline in our town centres. The five strands of the plan include ending ATM charges and bank branch and Post Office closures. Labour wants to boost bus services and provide free bus travel for under-25s, deliver free wi-fi to town centres, launch a register of landlords of empty shops and re-evaluate business rates annually. They also want to look at free parking. Ms Long-Bailey will tell the party conference: “Our high streets need saving from an agonising death.  Our country needs to radically change course so our towns can thrive again.” Around 100,000 shop jobs have been lost in three years, Labour analysis shows. House of Fraser, Marks &amp Spencer, New Look and Mothercare have all closed stores this year. title: no deal brexit plans revealed
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit plans revealed: 9 more startling official warnings and how they'll affect your leThe government have released their final pile of warnings. Here's how they'll affect what you doShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan Bloom17:12, 24 SEP 2018Updated19:04, 24 SEP 2018News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexiteers insisted negotiating our way out of the EU was going to be the easiest job in the world. But six months out from Brexit day it's looking more and more likely that we won't get a deal at all. And by the looks of these warnings from the government, that's going to mean a head-scratching mess of hassle, faff and red tape. Tory ministers today published their final pile of 24 papers, showing what will change for British businesses and consumers in the unlikely event of a no-deal outcome. It could cause havoc with flights and coach journeys and create a massive headache for truck drivers. And taking your pet abroad could mean a visit to the vet FOUR MONTHS ahead of time. Here are the most startling warnings from the final tranche of no-deal Brexit warnings, and what they could mean for you. 1. Taking your pet abroad? You could need to visit the vet four months in advance  The papers reveal a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. Currently, the main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners would have to visit a vet at least FOUR MONTHS before visiting the EU. This means pet owners intending to travel to the EU on 30 March 2019 would need to discuss requirements with their vet before the end of November 2018, the papers warn. The animal would have to have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least 30 days before travel, to prove the vaccination worked. Once that was completed, the pet owner would have to visit a vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than 10 days before the date the holiday starts. This is the worst case scenario. In another form of No Deal Brexit, the UK could be made a listed third country. This would increase red tape but not as much, with a visit to the vet only needed three weeks before travel.  British airlines hoping to fly planes between the bloc and the UK would have to win permission from each separate country, the latest Brexit technical notices said. European firms wanting to carry passengers between Britain and the continent would have to seek authority from the UK. The notice says: “In this scenario the UK would envisage granting permission to EU airlines to continue to operate. “We would expect EU countries to reciprocate in turn. “It would not be in the interest of any EU country or the UK to restrict the choice of destinations that could be served, though  such permissions are not granted, there could be disruption to some flights.” UK airlines would also lose the automatic right to fly planes between two EU destinations, such as Milan and Paris. 3. Planes might be grounded  they fail new safety checks  Planes issued with safety certicates in the UK could be grounded  European officials fail to recognise the accreditation, under a no-deal Brexit. EU officials could decide not to allow British pilots and aircraft certied by the UK's Civil Aviation Authority to operate in EU skies. Britain has said it would continue to recognise licences and certicated authorised by the Eureopan Aviation Safety Agency. But the technical notice says: “The EU has indicated that it would take a dferent approach to the UK. The information notices issued by the European Commission say that certicates previously issued by the before exit day would no longer be automatically accepted in the system after 29 March 2019.” Pilots and firms hoping to operate in the EU should consult the bloc, the note adds.  Qualications issued by CAA-approved organisations “would no longer be valid for use with EU operators after exit day”, the document warns. UK firms could also be shut out of maintenance contracts and supplying aircraft parts. 5. You might have to go through airport security TWICE  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit. Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport before changing flights for an onward destination would be screened in Britain as now. But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight. “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says the Department for Transport briefing note. “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.” 6. Truck drivers will need new permits - and there almost certainly won't be enough to go around  Thousands of truck drivers could be locked out of EU countries as their permits to carry freight across the continent become null and void. If there's a No Deal Brexit, UK hauliers will no longer have the automatic right to be let through EU nations' borders under the current permit system. Instead,  no other deal comes into force, they have to apply for an 'ECMT' permit - and there are only a set number of these available per year. For one type of these annual permits, just 984 are issued per year, the documents say. The no deal papers warn explicitly that demand for the permits will signicantly exceed supply and firms should prepare for getting fewer than they ask for. They will be allocated through a formula that was laid down in law earlier this year, and successful applicants will be contacted at the end of 2018. Haulage firms have been warned by the government to draw up contingency plans for  they end up unable to use some of their fleet. 7. Car insurance will get more complicated  Hauliers and holidaymakers driving to the EU will be forced to apply for a 'green card' to prove they have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting.  Meat and animal product imports from the EU, but which originate outside the EU, would be subject to additional checking at Border Inspection Posts. The government says staff will be trained to “minimise the impact” of the increased number of import checks, and “reduce the chance of delays.” 9. UK coach operators may lose access to the EU

story: AdvertorialWhy hidden toilets are now being unlocked across the countryDomestos has been calling on business owners to get on board with its Use Our Loos schemeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Masters12:07, 24 SEP 2018Updated16:08, 24 SEP 2018AdvertorialNew campaign aims to tackle the demise of public toilets"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've all experienced that frantic feeling of being out and about in need of the loo...but not being able to find one. story: NewsHow to recycle household goods to transform your old junk into treasureHere, DIY expert Jo Behari tells you how you can turn unwanted household objects into pieces of art that will help make a house a homeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Connor21:52, 24 SEP 2018NewsAre you someone with a stash of old junk that could be reused? "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe are holding on to enough leftover paint to cover the White Clfs of Dover 4,000 times, a new poll reveals. Half of the householders surveyed had between four and 20 tins of part-used paint stashed away around the house and garage, Dulux found.  Leftover paint is pretty useless – unless you have enough to do a whole room – and home improvement and DIY expert Jo Behari admits it fades quickly and is best given away to &shy recycling centres or local building firm and schools.  But she says there are plenty of other old bits and bobs you will have lying around that can be given a new lease of le. Here Jo reveals her top eight household hacks to get the most out of your leftovers. Old chipped mugs  Jo says of damaged mugs: “These are excellent to keep, especially  you do a lot of DIY. “You can use them to store paintbrushes during your decorating jobs, or even use them to mix products like filler or glue.” But she warns: “Make sure you sand down any sharp edges.” And  you’re a fan of gentle outdoor lighting, Jo says you can use the mug to house candles for your garden.  Wooden planks It’s a good idea to keep a few planks spare in case of damage to the ones on the floor. But for any leftovers you cannot , Jo says try these ideas:  Hardwood planks can be used to make planters for flowers. You could stick a few planks together to use as a doormat. If they are thick enough you can use them as shelving.  Jo says: “Most wood floors have a tongue or groove so you would need to find a way to trim the edges so they look finished. Most hardware stores have a range of trims that can be glued on to hide the edging.” Old carpet  Had a new carpet? Don’t throw the old one out just yet. A local carpet store can whip the edges – threading them so they look finished and don’t fray – and you can use any excess as a doormat. Or you could cut small squares and place them under heavy furniture to protect the carpet underneath. A small piece is also a good knee protector while gardening or doing household chores. And use your old carpet to protect that new carpet from attack by your cat. Jo says: “Wrap spare carpet round a pillar and use it as a scratching post.” Household items A iety of items you don’t need any more, such as food packaging and newspaper, can be put to good use.  Glass jars are great to store unfinished food from opened tins, such as baked beans. They can also store make-up brushes or kitchen utensils. Use cereal liner bags to crush nuts or biscuits for baking.  Newspaper can line pet litter trays, clean windows and soak up drips and mess from your fridge fruit and veg drawers. It’s also useful to keep kids busy making papier mache. “Kids love to paint a loo roll and call it a rocket,” says Jo.  Leftover house bricks Don’t leave your garden looking like a building site – put your old bricks to use in it. Jo says: “These are great for creating small props for wonky items.” They can also be handy as weights for a garden table cover when it’s windy, or to edge your walkway. Picture frames If the glass in your picture frame has broken or you have no picture to pop in it, don’t just chuck it away. A glass supplier may be able to make you a mirror out of an unwanted frame and Jo says: “Many of these places are small, locally run firms that would really appreciate the business.” Here are her ideas for other uses:  Stick cork tiles in the backing and create a pinboard. Make your kids feel like Monet and put their art in it. Thread wire across the back and put hooks at the bottom to make a jewellery hanger. Add mini shelves to store nail polish.

story: NewsImportant clue in Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's Royal Tour which hints at when we can expect pregnancy newsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry are heading to Australia and New Zealand for their first Royal Tour next monthShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor14:01, 24 SEP 2018Updated17:09, 24 SEP 2018NewsFans are very excited - but they might have to wait a while "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEver since Meghan Markle and Prince Harry said they wanted to start a family in the near future during their engagement interview, fans have been on royal baby countdown. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex both love kids, and we've seen they are complete naturals at a number of official engagements so far. Bookies have slashed the odds on the couple making a baby announcement before the end of the year , but there's one detail of their upcoming Royal Tour which could prove we'll have to wait a bit longer. Meghan and Harry's first overseas Royal Tour will take place next month when the couple will visit Australia and New Zealand.  During their 16-day trip they will also visit Fiji and Tonga, which are deemed moderate risk for the Zika virus. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, and while it isn't harmful for most people it can be very serious for pregnant women. It can cause birth defects, including abnormally small heads. The Government advises pregnant women to postpone non-essential travel until the end of their pregnancy. This means it is unlikely Meghan and Harry will be trying for a baby before their trip, as they won't want to cancel it  they do fall pregnant.  The Government also advises couples trying for a baby to avoid conception while they're away, and for up to six months after they get back. If they follow the advice, they won't start trying until April. Like most couples, royals normally wait until at least the 12 week scan before they tell anyone they're expecting - so it will be July at the earliest before we hear any exciting baby news. The Government website states: Zika virus infection may present an increased risk of complications for certain groups of the population, particularly pregnant women.  Although the probability of developing complications resulting from Zika infection is low, the impact of these complications, should they occur, are very serious. Travel advisories are therefore focused on pregnant women, their partners and couples planning pregnancy.

story: NewsLaura Plummer 'devastated' after losing appeal to overturn jail term for smuggling painkillers into EgyptThe 34-year-old from Hull said she 'just wants to come home' after judges upheld her three-year jail term for carrying 290 tramadol tablets into the countryShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy ThorntonNatalie Evans22:57, 24 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/brit-jailed-egypt-smuggling-painkillers-12375491,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jailed Brit Laura Plummer has spoken of her devastation after her latest bid for freedom was rejected by judges in Egypt .  The 34-year-old penned a heartbreaking letter from prison - saying she 'just wants to come home'. The former shop worker from Hull was jailed on Boxing Day last year for carrying hundreds of painkillers in her suitcase. She hoped the Egyptian appeal court would accept that she had no way of knowing the tramadol pills were banned.  But she was left in tears after judges in Cairo upheld her conviction and three-year prison sentence, The Sun reports .  Laura's Egyptian husband Omar Saad, 34, broke the news to her inside the notorious Al Qanater prison, where she is living in a squalid cell with 20 other women in 34C heat.   In a handwritten letter, given to The Sun , Laura said: I was sure they would see sense. This whole situation is just ridiculous. I just want to come home.  She also hit out at the UK Foreign Office, who she says refuses to intervene on her behalf. She added: How can they leave me in here? Laura was sentenced to three years in prison for carrying 290 tramadol tablets into the north African country while on holiday in October 2017. She was arrested and charged despite her pleas that the painkillers were for husband Omar’s bad back.  Speaking to The Sun, Laura said: What don’t these people get? I wonder  I’ve died and this is hell. What did I do that was so wrong in my le to end up here? I thought the appeal judges would see sense and realise I couldn’t have known the tablets were banned. It’s just so absurd.  Her older brother Kirk recently told of the “emotional rollercoaster” the whole family have been on since she was imprisoned. In an interview with Viking FM, Mr Plummer said: “I wouldn’t wish what me and my family are going through on anybody, nobody. “No one wants to see their daughter or sister in prison and  it happened to them then they would realise just how bad it is.  “But what we are going through is nothing compared to what Laura is going through in prison out there. “You sometimes just sit and think and it hits you again that she is still there and as a family we are trying to get on and lead a normal le but it’s hard and you are constantly reminded that she is still there with 20 other women sat on a cell floor. “The last six months have been an emotional rollercoaster and you get ups and downs. “One minute you are angry she even went to Egypt and then you get mad that she’s been arrested for what she did.”  Shortly into her imprisonment, one of Laura’s sisters, Jayne, revealed how Laura had been “kicked and punched” in jail and said she would be “amazed”  her younger sister survived her three-year ordeal. She was moved and is now being held in Qanatar Prison on the outskirts of Cairo.

story: NewsMum with locked-in syndrome who couldn't even breathe unassisted finally able to tell husband 'I love you'Norma Cullen, 69, developed rare neurological condition Guillain-Barré Syndrome after complications from a tummy bugShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLouie Smith21:07, 24 SEP 2018NewsNorma, pictured with husband Phil, described being in a bubble as she was struck down with the condition "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA women who could not communicate for four months except by blinking finally regained her voice and told her husband: “I love you.” Keen cyclist Norma Cullen, 69, suffered locked-in syndrome after complications from a tummy bug. Paralysed and unable even to breathe unaided after developing the rare neurological condition Guillain-Barr&eacute Syndrome, the grandmother emerged from weeks of sedation unable to move anything but her eyes. She said: “You really are locked in. It’s like you’re in a bubble. “To have all these thoughts and not be able to express them was the height of frustration.”  At first her family used an alphabet board to help her spell out what she wanted to say. But it could take half an hour to finish a sentence, so she started to spell out just one word then blink yes or no to questions. Gradually Norma began to improve, able to move her head, shrug and smile. Finally doctors fitted a speaking valve to the tracheotomy through which she was being ventilated – and she saved her precious first words for husband Phil, 69. Norma from St Ives, Cornwall, recalled: “When Phil came in I said, ‘I couldn’t tell you yesterday but I can today. I love you.’

title: mum two autistic boys claims
story: NewsMum of two autistic boys claims man 'threatened to strangle her eldest' during campaign of abuse by other parentsGemma Ryan, 35, has two autistic sons but says the hurtful comments from other parents are a regular occurrenceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRebecca HusselbeeAmy Coles16:19, 24 SEP 2018Updated16:34, 24 SEP 2018NewsMembers of the public often assume her sons, William, 10, and Edward, six, are naughty children who need firm handling "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-two claims a dad threatened to strangle her eldest boy during a campaign of abuse against her autistic sons. Gemma Ryan, 35, from Heanor, Derby, has said the abuse has gone on for years. She says it has been so severe she has often been met with outrage from members of the public who believe her sons, William, 10, and Edward, six, are 'naughty children' who need firm handling. In reality that both William and Edward suffer from autism, with Edward also suffering for ADHD and Tourettes. Both boys can make loud noises or flap their arms when anxious and Edward suffers uncontrollable ticks.   Mum-of-two Gemma said: I had gone to the playcentre on my own with the boys during the school holidays , at a time I thought would be a bit quieter so it would be easier for them to play and avoid any confrontation.  A mum had made a comment that I should keep my 'weird' boys away from her son and that I needed to understand they shouldn't be here. I was determined that I would not be going anywhere and I took Edward to the toilet while William carried on playing. I overheard the woman in the bathroom saying to her son that she needed to hurry up on the toilet so she could get back and not leave her other child playing with William without supervision. I confronted her and told her my son was not weird and that she needed to educate herself on these kinds of conditions. Within ten minutes another man arrived with a child and he was playing nicely with William before William put his arm around him.  The dad suddenly went mad and started swearing, saying  my son touched his child again he was going to strangle him. I was completely flabbergasted. Other people stood up to defend me and he started banging tables before he was asked to leave. My legs fell under me. I collapsed onto the floor sobbing and crying and put my arms around my kids. After the incident in August 2016, Gemma was only able to  to the centre a year later with the support of her husband, David, 41, but claims she has been faced with constant abuse from people who mistake the boy's behaviour for 'naughtiness'. Gemma recalls a lady in a coffee shop tutting at the boys making noises and flapping their arms, a common symptom of autism, with Gemma defending her boys and asking the lady not to worry as the disorder was 'not contagious.' She said: We have been faced with a number of occasions where people don't understand that being in a new environment can make the boys anxious and can make their behaviour worse, especially Edwards ticks. William is starting to understand more and more that he is not the same as others and that people will often him treat him dferently, while Edward is still not old enough to understand.  William was asked to attend a Halloween Party one year and then was not invited back the next and he asked me why which was really hard to explain.  The couple have now decided to raise awareness in the hopes it will help make those with autism feel more included and to help educate others on the disorder.

title: queen secret door hidden drawing
story: NewsThe Queen has a secret door hidden in this drawing room at Buckingham Palace - can you spot it?Her Majesty uses the door to move between her private apartments and the State RoomsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience17:26, 24 SEP 2018Updated17:38, 24 SEP 2018NewsThis family snap was taken in the White Drawing Room, where the door is hidden "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMany little boys and girls dream of being princes and princesses, living in vast palaces with secret doors that lead to hidden passages.  For Queen Elizabeth II , this was a reality. Aside from the fact she's actual royalty, she has a pretty cool secret door - and she still uses it to this day.  In fact, you or I could see this palace secret close up and in person. It's in one of the beautul State Rooms, which are open to the public every summer, and palace staff leave the door ajar so you can peek through. At a glance, the White Drawing Room at the rear of the palace looks just like any other room. Stunning chandeliers hang from the ceiling, an intricate red carpet blankets the floor and ornate golden gilding covers the ceiling and walls.  On either side of the white fireplace are two enormous mirrors behind dressers - but one isn't what it seems. You wouldn't know it  you were just walking through, but the mirror on the left of the photograph actually opens up to reveal a secret door behind it.  Ornaments are permanently glued to the dresser so there's no danger of anything falling off and breaking. The door leads to Her Majesty's private apartments, allowing her direct access to the State Rooms for s and events. The Queen throws open the doors to Buckingham Palace every summer so that the public can tour the State Rooms while she holidays in Balmoral, her Scottish home.  While the private apartments are obviously off limits to guests, tourists can enjoy tours of the rooms where the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh welcome visitors from all over the world. You can also walk around the Throne Room, where the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge posed for their official wedding photos, and see the throne made specically for the Queen's coronation. Perhaps most impressive is the Ballroom, where the Royals host state dinners for more than 100 guests.

title: tens thousands brits could infected
story: NewsTens of thousands of Brits could be infected by hepatitis viruses and HIV in contaminated blood scandal, inquiry hearsA public probe will consider the treatment of thousands of people in the 1970s and 1980s who were given infected blood productsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGeorgina Stubbs19:27, 24 SEP 2018NewsThousands of haemophiliacs and other patients in the UK were given infected blood products over two decades  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTens of thousands of Brits could be infected as a result of the contaminated blood scandal, an inquiry has heard.  A public probe will consider the treatment of thousands of people in the 1970s and 1980s who were given blood products infected with hepatitis viruses and HIV, and the impact this has had. Chairman of the inquiry, retired judge Sir Brian Langstaff, addressed hundreds of people who attended the start of the Infected Blood Inquiry in London today. He said: It is a truly sobering thought that  some of the claims are well-founded - and it is for this inquiry to find out  they are - there may yet be many thousands more who do not feel well, but have not yet been told that the reason for this is that they suffer from Hepatitis C.  Sir Brian said it is estimated that the number of infected could go far beyond 25,000 adding that there is a real chance that these estimates may prove right. He added: A sobering thought that the consequences of what was done then may be continuing to cause death even now.  Victim Michelle Tolley spoke as the probe into the deaths of more than 2,400 people who were infected with HIV and Hepatitis C as a result of the scandal began. Anyone who may be responsible... they need to be held accountable and prosecuted  needs be - I strongly believe that, the mother-of-four from Norfolk told the Press Association. People need to know that this tragedy happened, she said. This is the worst tragedy in the history of the NHS and it must never ever happen again, absolutely never. The 53-year-old was infected following a blood transfusion after the birth of her child in 1987 and another transfusion in 1991 - she eventually found out in 2015 that she had Hepatitis C. Describing how she wakes up every day feeling as though she is waiting to die, she said she thought seeing the start of the inquiry would be a day that would never come, and worries she might not see it end. Feeling very positive about the inquiry and that prosecutions could be achieved, she added: I have great, great faith that they will leave no stone unturned.  Sir Brian told those gathered that people will be at the heart of the inquiry, as well as ensuring it is properly funded, and independent of the Government. He also revealed that the inquiry will be UK-wide and will not confine itself to London - with the aim to conduct hearings all over the country to enable more affected people to come in person. And with allegations of a cover-up, which he said will be investigated, SiFr Brian stressed that the probe will be as open and transparent as it is legally possible to be. According to the terms of reference, which were published in July, the inquiry will consider whether there have been attempts to conceal details of what happened through the destruction of documents or withholding of information. It will also consider  those attempts were deliberate and  there has been a lack of openness or candour in the response of the Government, NHS bodies and other officials to those affected. During her opening statement, counsel to the inquiry Jenni Richards QC, said the terms of reference were a product of public consultation, describing it as a moving, humbling, and enlightening process. The inquiry does not underestimate the scale of the task which it faces, she said. It recognises that this is an immense undertaking which will require an enormous amount of work. Noting the breadth of issues and decades over which the scandal took place as another reason for the scale of the inquiry, she also cited the 100,000 documents already in the possession of the probe - a figure she said is likely to increase. She also revealed that they intend for the inquiry to begin hearing evidence on April 30 next year, and how the aim is to sit three weeks out of every four, and up to four days a week. Unable to give what she deemed a reliable answer as to how long the inquiry will take, Ms Richards confirmed that the process will not take less than a year and a quarter.

story: NewsWeightWatchers reveals new name without the word 'weight' - but bosses can't say what it meansWeightWatchers wants to focus on overall health rather than just losing weight, and bosses say the new name is just the startShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor19:56, 24 SEP 2018Updated21:07, 24 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/weight-watchers-drops-weight-13301058,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDiet giant WeightWatchers has revealed it is changing its name and dropping the word 'weight' as part of a huge evolution. The company has rebranded as WW with the tag line Wellness that Works in a bid to focus on overall health rather than just losing weight. The company's chief executive Mindy Grossman said the new name is the the next stage of the company's evolution, and the brand has promised lots of other exciting changes in the near future. However she said the WW doesn't stand for Wellness that Works - but wouldn't say what it actually meant.  She said: We are committed to always being the best weight management program on the planet, but now we're putting our decades of knowledge and expertise in behavioral science to work for an even greater mission. We are becoming the world's partner in wellness. No matter what your goal is – to lose weight, eat healthier, move more, develop a positive mind-set, or all of the above – we will deliver science-based solutions that fit into people's lives.  This is just the beginning of our journey to become the world's partner in wellness, and I am inspired by the potential for our impact.  Earlier this year the company also announced it was dropping before and after photos in a bid to promote long-term change.  The company's website has already been branded, and the app will now include lots of more general health features for customers to enjoy. American chat show host Oprah Winfrey, who uses the programme and now works to promote the charity, has thrown her support behind the new brand.  She said: From the moment I chose to invest in the company and join the Board, I have believed that the role WW can play in people's lives goes far beyond a number on the scale. As Weight Watchers becomes WW, I believe we will continue to inspire people not only to eat well, but to move more, connect with others and continue to experience the joys of a healthy le. WW has also launched a new programme - WellnessWins - which will give customers rewards  they complete small, everyday healthy behaviours.

title: woman thinks new roommate covered
story: NewsWoman thinks new roommate has covered walls in photos of singers - but soon discovers she's hiding creepy secretA university student is afraid to stay in her own room after learning her roommate has a very creepy secretShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer16:16, 24 SEP 2018NewsA woman has discovered her roommate was hiding a disturbing secret  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Moving into university accommodation is a bizarre experience.  On the one hand, it's exciting, because you're getting out of the house and learning to stand on your own two feet, but on the other it's troubling because you're now living with a bunch of people you don't know. Like Forrest Gump once said: Le is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're gonna get. And when it comes to the people living in your flat, they could be your new best friends or the worst people you've ever met. One woman found out the hard way just how strange living with a stranger can actually be.   The unnamed student has been living at university for three weeks and just discovered her new roommate, Leanne , is hiding a very creepy secret.   She explained the bizarre story in a letter to Slate's agony aunt , Prudence.  Leanne had covered her part of the room in pictures of men and she had assumed they were of indie rock stars but it turns out they were much more sinister.   I thought she was a hipster who put up pictures of old indie rock stars on her wall, explained the roommate. Then my friend came to our dorm and told me the dudes in her pictures were serial killers : Ted Bundy, Jeffrey Dahmer, Ed Gein.  I freaked out and asked Leanne to take them down, but she refuses. She won’t explain why she put the pictures up, which also freaks me out. She added: I hate looking at pictures of these evil people and have been spending nights in my friends’ dorms. I have to wait to transfer rooms until there’s an opening. Leanne and I barely talk now. I’m not someone who enjoys horror films, and I get scared easily. I want to be comfortable in my room, and I’m not sure how to do that. Am I being immature for not getting over this?  The agony aunt advised her that it was indeed reasonable and mature to not want images of serial killers on her bedroom walls and suggested she get the housing office involved  things didn't improve. Many people reading the column were shocked by her story. One person commented saying she should retaliate by putting up pictures of the killers' victims. Another said: I doubt I would want horror movie posters up in my dorm room, but at least that's someone appreciating a form of art. This smacks of appreciating actual murderers, which is highly creepy.

But as the ride gets underway the boy tried to sit on the metal bars securing the open window of cabin when he slipped. title: three day old baby girl
story: NewsThree-day-old baby girl survives being stung SEVEN times by deadly yellow scorpion that crawled into nappyMaria Sofia was just three days old when her mum discovered the insect inside her nappyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJanet Tappin Coelho14:38, 24 SEP 2018Updated15:03, 24 SEP 2018NewsThe yellow scorpion has a poisonous sting "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA three-day old baby girl has been called a 'miracle' by doctors after she survived being stung by a yellow scorpion seven times. The venomous insect that crawled into Maria Sofia Ferreira's nappy and had attached itself to her umbilical cord. It then stung her over half a dozen times, causing her to go limp and started foaming at the mouth. Her mum, Fernanda, 25, said that she knew something was wrong around ten minutes after she had given her a bath and put a new nappy on. Doctors said that the child, from Brazil, only survived because she was given multiple doses of antidote within a two-hour time frame. The mum said: Sofia felt really soft and weak. She didn't want to be nursed and was struggling to breathe.  I thought she had reflux. I had no idea a scorpion was buried in her diaper and had bitten her seven times. The baby was rushed to hospital in Vitoria da Conquista, Bahia state, northeast Brazil, suffering from an accelerated heartbeat, excessive saliva and a severe loss of appetite. At one point her condition plummeted to dangerous levels and she stopped breathing. She was given six emergency doses of anti-corticosteroid serum and after spending three days in intensive care the newborn, now three weeks old, was discharged and has since made a full recovery. On Sunday the pediatrician who cared for the young patient spoke for the first time of her shock at finding the eight-legged arachnid still alive and clinging to the baby's umbilical stump.  I was so frightened when I opened up Sofia's diaper and uncovered the scorpion. I panicked because I was too scared to take the insect off myself, so I ran to ask for help from a security guard who removed the creature, admitted Dr Camila Mirante at the Esa Matos Municipal Hospital. The baby was treated on the September 6 and transferred to an intensive care unit in the city's general hospital where she was monitored until her health stabilised and then discharged three days later. Mrs Ferreira revealed medical staff at a health unit where she first took her daughter, failed to spot the scorpion despite checking the child over. Instead, like her, they suspected she was suffering from reflux. Fortunately, the unit's doctor decided to drive the child in her own car to the municipal hospital after becoming concerned her symptoms were le-threatening.  The mum of three, said: I don't blame the doctor for not finding the scorpion. It was the last thing anyone suspected. It was only after doctors at the municipal hospital completely undressed Sofia that they discovered the scorpion hidden in her nappy. I was in a state of shock when I learned that my daughter had been bitten seven times by a scorpion. I began to cry with my husband, Magno, because we were convinced our child was going to die. Daniel Rebou as, director of Bahia Health Secretariat Information Centre, said: Children up to seven years of age, who are victims of scorpion stings, should be treated, at most, within two hours of being bitten. This is the period in which the poison is still circulating in the body and the anti-corticosteroid serum is able to work effectively. The frightened mum suspects the scorpion entered the home through a drain in the bathroom and climbed up a cupboard piled with nappies which was also where she changed her daughter.

title: 500k to be pumped into dundee health centre
story: Lochee Health Centre is set to undergo four months of improvement works.The project will see £500,000 pumped into the GP practice on Marshall Street and NHS Tayside have said there will be no change to appointments for patients.Improvements include upgrades to the entrance and patient waiting rooms.Shared accommodation will also be provided along with the introduction of a new cancer wellbeing service.Councillor Ken Lynn, chairman of the Dundee Integration Joint Board, said: “Lochee Health Centre is a vital part of local primary care services in Dundee and this improvement work will further enhance the range of services provided for the community of Lochee.“The newly refurbished Lochee Health Community Care Centre will benefit patients and members of the community by continuing to deliver high-quality health and social care services right in the heart of Lochee.”

title: ambitious proposal for 6000 capacity concert hall and cafe in dundee
story: Plans for a 6,000-capacity concert hall in Dundee have been revealed. 100vw, 667px" /The ambitious proposal would see the Mecca Bingo in the Nethergate transformed into Scotland’s fourth-largest concert venue.It would have an all-seated capacity of 4,775 over three tiers that could be expanded to 6,375 by incorporating standing room on the ground floor.Glasgow-based architects Wilson+Gunn created the designs as part of a feasibility study commissioned by the property developers who own the building.The study states the roof of the building could be removed to extend it upwards, with the Nethergate entrance extensively restructured to include a restaurant or café. The rear of the building, on Yeaman Shore, would also be remodelled to create an entrance.Internally, the building would have 102 underground car parking spaces.The ground floor would contain the auditorium, a bar, toilets and ticket office.There would be further bars and balcony spectator seating on the first floor, while the second floor would have a corporate dining area and upper deck seating.Architect Kenny Stephen said: “We were commissioned to do a feasibility study to see how a 5,000 to 6,000-capacity venue could be realised.”Mr Stephen said redeveloping the Mecca Bingo building would be cheaper than building a new concert hall from the ground up.He said: “It makes more sense than building from scratch.“Bingo seems to be in decline, with more people playing online, so it may be another use for the building.”
